Arabic: وذلك كل ما أُكل مما بيع موزوناً، لأني وجدتها مجتمعةَ المعاني في أنها مأكولة ومشروبة، والمشروبُ في معنى المأكول، لأنه كلَّه للناس إما قوت وإما غذاء وإما هما،
English: Accordingly, this applied to any foodstuffs sold by weight, because I have found them to share the same principle, whether solid or liquid—and what is liquid is covered by the same rationale as what is solid—since they are all staples, foodstuffs, or both.

Arabic: ووجدت الناس شَحّوا عليها حتى باعوها وزناً، والوزنُ أقربُ من الإحاطة من الكيل، وفي معنى الكيل،
English: I have also found people so concerned about accuracy in measuring these things that they came to be sold by weight, and weight may be more accurate than volume and covered by the same rationale for these purposes.

Arabic: وذلك مثل العسل والسمن والزيت والسكر وغيره، مما يؤكل ويُشرب ويباع موزوناً.
English: These include honey, clarified butter, olive oil, sugar, and other solid and liquid foodstuffs sold by weight.

Arabic: فإن قال قائل: أفيحتمل ما بيع موزوناً أن يقاس [ص:525] على الوزن من الذهب والوَرِق، فيكونَ الوزن بالوزن أولى بأن يقاس من الوزن بالكيل؟
English: If someone were to say, “Is it possible that foodstuffs sold by weight be governed by an analogy from gold and silver sold by weight, so that analogizing from one thing sold by weight to another sold by weight would be better than analogizing from sales by weight to sales by volume?”

Arabic: قيل – إن شاء الله – له: إن الذي منعنا مما وصفتَ – من قياس الوزن بالوزن – أن صحيح القياس إذا قِست الشيء بالشيء أن تحكم له بحكمه،
English: One should reply, God willing: What keeps us from accepting what you have described, to wit, analogizing from sales of some things based on weight to sales of other things based on weight, is that a valid analogy involves comparing two things and then applying the ruling of the one to the other.

Arabic: فلو قست العسل والسمن بالدنانير والدراهم، وكنت إنما حرّمت الفضل في بعضها على بعض إذا كانت جنساً واحدا قياساً على الدنانير والدراهم: أكان يجوز أن يُشترى بالدنانير والدراهم نقداً عسلاً وسمناً إلى أجل؟
English: So, for example, if you were to analogize honey and sesame oil to dinars and dirhams, and you had only made it unlawful that one of the exchanged items exceed the other if they were of the same kind, would it be permissible to use dinars and dirhams as immediate payment to purchase honey and clarified butter for delayed delivery?

Arabic: فإن قال: يجيزه بما أجازه به المسلمون.[ص:526] قيل إن شاء الله: فإجازة المسلمين له دلتني على أنه غير قياس عليه،
English: If he says, “You would permit such a transaction for the same reason that Muslims permit it,” one would reply, God willing: The fact that the Muslims permit this indicates to me that the permission for it is not arrived at by means of analogy.

Arabic: لو كان قياساً عليه كان حكمُه حكمَه، فلم يحل أن يباع إلا يداً بيد، كما لا تحل الدنانير بالدراهم إلا يداً بيد.
English: If it were based on analogical reasoning, then the same rule would apply to both, and it would not be lawful that they be sold except as a present exchange, just as it is not lawful to exchange dinars for dirhams except in a present exchange.

Arabic: فإن قال: أفتجدك حين قسته على الكيل حكمتَ له حكمه؟قلت: نعم، لا أفرّق بينه في شيء بحال.
English: If it is said, “Do you find that when you analogize from a volume sale, you use the same ruling for sales by weight?” I would say: Yes, I do not distinguish between them at all, in any circumstance.

Arabic: قال: أفلا يجوز أن تشتري مُدّ حِنطة نقداً بثلاثة أرطال زيت إلى أجل.
English: “Is it not permissible,” he asked, “for you to buy a mudd of wheat delivered immediately for three raṭls of olive oil with delayed delivery?”

Arabic: [ص:527] قلت: لا يجوز أن يُشترى، ولا شيءٌ من المأكول والمشروب بشيء من غير صنفه إلى أجل.
English: It is not permissible, I replied, to exchange any foodstuffs or beverages at all for a different foodstuff for delayed delivery.

Arabic: حكمُ المأكول المكيلِ حكمُ المأكول الموزون. ِ
English: The ruling for foodstuffs sold by volume is the same as the ruling for foodstuffs sold by weight.

Arabic: قال: فما تقول في الدنانير والدراهم؟
English: “What do you say,” he asked, “about the application of this prohibition to dinars and dirhams?”

Arabic: قلت: محرَّمات في أنفسها، لا يقاس شيء من المأكول عليها، لأنه ليس في معناها،
English: Such exchanges of them would be unlawful on their own and not ever to be analogized to foodstuffs, since they implicate a different rationale.

Arabic: والمأكولُ المكيلُ محرَّم في نفسه، ويقاس به ما في معناه من المكيل والموزون عليه، لأنه في معناه.
English: It is inherently unlawful to exchange foodstuffs sold by volume, but one can make them the basis for an analogy with other things sold by volume and weight because those other things are covered by the same rationale—and it is possible to draw this analogy precisely because the rationale is the same in both cases.

Arabic: فإن قال: فافرُق بين الدنانير والدراهم؟قلت: لم أعلم مخالفاً من أهل العلم في إجازة أن يُشترى بالدنانير والدراهم الطعامُ المكيلُ والموزون إلى أجل، وذلك لا يحل في الدنانير بالدراهم،
English: If he says, “Explain how dinars and dirhams are different from foodstuffs,” I would reply, I know of no one among the scholars who disagrees concerning the permissibility of purchasing foodstuffs by volume or weight, using dinars or dirhams, for delayed delivery. But that is not lawful when exchanging dinars and dirhams.

Arabic: وإني لم أعلم منهم مخالفاً في أني لو علمت مَعدِناً فأدّيت الحق فيما خرج منه، ثم أقامت فضته أو ذهبه عندي دهرِي: كان علي في كل سنة أداءُ زكاتها،
English: And I know of no one among them who disagrees that if I discovered a mine and paid my alms assessment from what I extracted from it, and then the silver or gold from it remained with me for a long time, I would have to pay alms on them every year.

Arabic: ولو حصدت [ص:528] طعامَ أرضي، فأخرجت عُشره أقام عندي دهرَه: لم يكن علي فيه زكاة،
English: And if I were to harvest the produce of my land and paid the tithe and then it remained in my keeping for a while, I would not have to pay alms on it.

Arabic: وفي أني لو استهلكت لرجل شيئاً قُوِّم علي دنانيرَ أو دراهمَ، لأنها الأثمانُ في كل مالٍ لمسلم إلا الديات.
English: Also, if I tortiously converted something that belonged to someone else, my liability for it would be calculated in dinars or dirhams, since they are the media of exchange for any property owned by a Muslim except for the blood-price.

Arabic: فإن قال: هكذا.قلتُ: فالأشياء تتفرق بأقل مما وصفت لك.
English: If he says, “So it is,” then I would say: Some matters are distinguishable on even fewer grounds than what I have just described for you.

Arabic: ووجدنا عامّاً في أهل العلم أن رسول الله قضى في جناية الحر المسلم خطأً بمائة من الإبل على عاقلة الجاني
English: . . .We find generally among the scholars the view that God’s Emissary ruled in cases of mistaken killing of a free Muslim by another that one hundred camels should be paid, for which the kin-group of the tortfeasor was liable.

Arabic: وعامَّاً فيهم أنها في مُضِيّ ثلاث سنين، في كل سنة ثلثُها، وبأسنانٍ معلومة.
English: It is also generally held by them that these are to be paid over three years, one-third each year, and that they are to consist of specific kinds of camels of specific, known age ranges.

Arabic: فدَلَّ على معاني من القياس، سأذكر منها – إن شاء الله – بعض ما يحضرني:
English: This example indicates several underlying points relating to analogical reasoning. I will mention those that come to mind, God willing.

Arabic: إنا وجدنا عاماً في أهل العلم أن ما جنى الحرُّ المسلم من جنايةِ عمدٍ أو فسادِ مال لأحد على نفس أو غيره: ففي ماله دون عاقلته، وما كان من جنايةٍ في نفسٍ خطأً فعلى عاقلته.
English: We find that the scholars generally hold that liability for intentional injuries to persons and property, whether a life is taken or not, is payable out of the tortfeasor’s own property, not that of his kin-group. Liability for unintentional killing is the kin-group’s.

Arabic: ثم وجدناهم مجمعين على أن تَعقل العاقلة ما بلغ ثلث الدية من جناية في الجراح فصاعداً.
English: Then, we find they have reached consensus to the effect that the kin-group pays one-third of the blood-price and up for injuries to the person.

Arabic: ثم افترقوا فيما دون الثلث:
English: Their views diverge, however, for what is below onethird of that amount.

Arabic: فقال بعض أصحابنا: تعقل العاقلة الموضِحَة وهي نصف العشر فصاعداً، ولا تعقل ما دونها.
English: Some of our associates say that the kin-group pays nothing if the amount is less than one-third. Others say that it pays for serious wounds that lay bare the bone—that is, onetwentieth and up—but not for anything less.

Arabic: فقلت لبعض من قال: تعقل نصف العشر، ولا تعقل ما دونه: هل يستقيم القياس على السنة إلا بأحد وجهين؟[ص:530] قال: وما هما؟
English: I said to someone who held the view that the kin-group was liable for one-twentieth and not for anything below that: Can analogical reasoning be properly applied to Prophetic Practice in any but one of two ways? “What are they?” he asked.

Arabic: قلت: أن تقول: لما وجدت النبي قضى بالدية على العاقلة قلت به اتباعاً،
English: I said: When you say: “When I found the Prophet holding that the kin-group should pay the blood-price, I adopted that opinion as a precedent.

Arabic: فما كان دون الدية ففي مال الجاني، ولا تقيس على الدية غيرها، لأن الأصل: الجاني أولى أن يَغْرَمَ جنايته من غيره، كما يغرمها في غير الخطأ في الجراح،
English: So whatever is less than the full blood-price is payable out of the property of the tortfeasor,” and you do not reason by analogy in this case from the full blood-price to cases involving other amounts because the presumption is that it is more appropriate for the tortfeasor to be liable for his own tort than someone else, just as he is liable therefor in the case of intentional injuries.

Arabic: وقد أوجب الله على القاتل خطأً ديةً ورقبةً،
English: After all, God has obligated someone who commits an unintentional killing to pay the full amount and to free a slave.

Arabic: فزعمت أن الرقبة في ماله، لأنها من جنايته، وأخرجت الدية من هذا المعنى اتباعاً،
English: Thus, you hold that the slave should come from his own property, since the liability arises from his tort, and you exempt the blood-price from that principle, based on precedent.

Arabic: وكذلك أتَّبع في الدية، وأصرف بما دونها إلى أن يكون في ماله، لأنه أولى أن يَغرم ما جنى من غيره،
English: I, too, follow precedent in regard to the blood-price and make what is less than the full blood-price payable from his property since it is more appropriate that he be liable for his tort than someone else.

Arabic: وكما أقول في المسح على الخفين: رخصةٌ: بالخبر عن رسول الله، ولا أقيس عليه غيرَه.
English: This is just like what I hold concerning the wiping of footwear: it is a dispensation based on a report from God’s Emissary; I will not use an analogy to reason from it to other cases.

Arabic: أو يكونَ القياس من وجه ثاني؟قال: وما هو؟
English: But is it possible that analogical reasoning could be employed in another way here? “What is that?” he asked.

Arabic: [ص:531] قلت: إذ أخرج رسول الله الجناية خطأً على النفس مما جنى الجاني على غير النفس، وما جنى على نفس عمداً، فجعل على عاقلته يضمنونها، وهي الأكثر: جَعَلْت على عاقلته يضمنون الأقل من جناية الخطأ،
English: I said: When God’s Emissary distinguished unintentional killing both from torts other than homicide and from intentional homicide, and then made the tortfeasor’s kin-group liable for the blood-price in cases of unintentional homicide, it being the larger amount, I made the kin-group liable for smaller amounts in the case of accidental injury.

Arabic: لأن الأقل أولى أن يضمنوه عنه من الأكثر، أو في مثل معناه.
English: This was because it was more appropriate that they should be liable, on his behalf, for the lesser amount, in comparison with the greater amount, or that the lesser amount be considered to be covered by the same rationale as the greater amount.

Arabic: قال: هذا أولى المعنيين أن يقاس عليه، ولا يُشْبهُ هذا المسحَ على الخفين.فقلت له: هذا كما قلت – إن شاء الله –
English: “That,” he said, “is the better of the two principles on which to base an analogy, but it does not resemble the wiping of the footwear.” That is as you say, I said, God willing.

Arabic: وأهل العلم مجمعون على أن تغرم العاقلة الثلث وأكثر، وإجماعهم دليل على أنهم قد قاسوا بعضَ ما هو أقلُّ من الدية بالدية!قال: أجل.
English: Scholars have reached consensus on the kin-group’s liability for one-third of the full amount and up, and their consensus indicates that they used analogical reasoning to compare something that was less than the full amount of the blood-price with the full amount. “Yes,” he said.

Arabic: فقلت له: فقد قال صاحبنا: أحسنُ ما سمعت أن تَغرم العاقلة ثلث الدية فصاعداً، وحكى أنه الأمرُ عندهم،
English: I said to him: Our associate says: “The best I have heard is that the kin-group incurs liability for one-third of the full blood-price and up,” and he related that it was their practice there.

Arabic: أفرأيت إن احتجّ له محتجّ بحجتين؟قال: وما هما؟
English: What if someone were to adduce two authorities in response? “What are they?” he asked.

Arabic: قلت: أنا وأنت مجمعان على أن تغرم العاقلة الثلث فأكثر، ومختلفان فيما هو أقل منه،
English: You and I have reached consensus, I said, to the effect that the kin-group is liable for one-third of the blood-price and more, but we disagree about lesser amounts.

Arabic: وإنما قامت الحجة بإجماعي وإجماعك على الثلث، ولا خبر عندك في أقلَّ منه: ما تقول له؟
English: Binding authority is established by virtue of your and my consensus on the one-third, and you have no report that addresses what is less than that. How would you respond to that?

Arabic: قال: أقول إن إجماعي من غير هذا الوجه الذي ذهبتَ إليه،
English: “I would say,” he replied, “that the consensus from my side has a different basis than the conclusion you reached.

Arabic: إجماعي إنما هو قياس على أن العاقلة إذا غَرِمت الأكثر ضَمنَت ما هو أقلُّ منه،
English: The consensus from my side is merely based on an analogy from the fact that if the kin-group incurs liability for the greater amount, then it is liable for smaller amounts, too.

Arabic: فمن حَدّ لك الثلث؟ أرأيت إن قال لك غيرك: بل تغرم تسعةَ أعشار، ولا تغرم ما دونه؟
English: Who made the one-third the limit for you? What if someone else were to say, ‘Rather, the kin-group incurs liability for nine-tenths but not for any amount less than that’?”

Arabic: قلت: فإن قال لك: فالثلث يَفدح مَن غَرِمه، [ص:533] قلت: يُغرم معه أو عنه لأنه فادح، ولا يُغرَم ما دونه غيرُ فادح.
English: What if, I replied, someone responded by saying, “The liability for onethird is too burdensome for the one who incurs it, whether I hold that he pay it jointly or that it be paid on his behalf. So it is because it is burdensome, and he is not liable for what is less than that because it is not burdensome.”

Arabic: قال: أفرأيت من لا مال له إلا درهمين، أما يَفدحه أن يَغرم الثلث والدرهمَ، فيبقى لا مال له؟ أرأيت من له دنيا عظيمةٌ، هل يفدحه الثلث؟
English: “What about someone,” he asked, “who has no money except for two dirhams? Is it burdensome for him to become liable for the one-third, so that he pays the two dirhams and has no money left? And what about someone whose worldly wealth is enormous? Is the one-third burdensome for him?”

Arabic: فقلت له: أفرأيت لو قال لك: هو لا يقول لك “الأمر عندنا” إلا والأمر مجتمَعٌ عليه بالمدينة.
English: What if, I replied, someone said to you: “He would not say ‘In our view, the matter is . . .’ unless that matter were agreed upon in Medina”?

Arabic: [ص:534] قال: والأمر المجتَمَع عليه بالمدينة أقوى من الأخبار المنفردة؟! قال: فكيف تَكلّفَ أن حكى لنا الأضعفَ من الأخبار المنفردة، وامتنع أن يحكيَ لنا الأقوى اللازمَ من الأمر المجتَمَع عليه؟!
English: “Is a matter agreed upon in Medina stronger than isolated reports?” he asked. “Why,” he continued, “did he take the trouble to relate to us something weaker than isolated reports and refuse to relate to us what is stronger—and thus binding—than the agreed upon practice?”

Arabic: قلنا: فإن قال لك قائل: لقلة الخبر وكثرة الإجماع عن أن يحُكى، وأنت قد تصنع مثل هذا، فتقول: هذا أمر مجتَمَع عليه!
English: What if, we replied, someone were to say to you, “Because of the paucity of reports and the fact that consensus is so ample that it does not need to be related. You might do the same thing when you say that something is agreed upon”?

Arabic: قال: لستُ أقول ولا أحدٌ من أهل العلم “هذا مجتمع عليه “: إلا لما تَلْقى عالماً أبداً إلا قاله لك وحكاه عن من قبله، كالظهرُ أربعٌ، وكتحريم الخمر، وما أشبه هذا،
English: “Neither I nor any scholar would say that it is agreed upon,” he replied, “unless every single scholar one meets expresses that opinion to you and relates it from those before him—such as the opinion that the noon prayer consists of four bowings, that wine is unlawful, and similar things.

Arabic: وقد أجده [ص:535] يقول: “المجمع عليه” وأجد من المدينة من أهل العلم كثيراً يقولون بخلافه، وأجد عامة أهل البلدان على خلاف ما يقول: “المجتمع عليه”
English: Moreover, I might find him saying ‘what is agreed upon’ and then find scholars from Medina frequently holding the opposite opinion and even that the majority of scholars in other regions hold the opposite of what he says is agreed upon.”

Arabic: قال: فقلت له: فقد يلزمك في قولك “لا تعقل ما دون الموضِحَة “مثلُ ما لزمه في الثلث.
English: You are compelled by your opinion that the kin-group is not liable for what is less than the wound that lays bone bare, I said, just as he is in his view about the one-third.

Arabic: فقال لي: إن فيه علةً بأن رسول الله لم يقض فيما دون الموضحة بشيء.
English: “There is an underlying reason,” he said to me, “which is that God’s Emissary did not issue any ruling at all about what is less than the wound that lays bone bare.”

Arabic: فقلت له: أفرأيت إن عارضك معارِض فقال: لا أقضي فيما دون الموضحة بشيء، لأن رسول الله لم يقض فيه بشيء؟
English: What if someone were to object, I asked him, by saying, “I will never rule at all in regard to what is less than such a wound, since God’s Emissary did not issue any ruling about it at all”?

Arabic: قال: ليس ذلك له، وهو إذا لم يقض فيما دونها بشيء، فلم يَهدُر ما دونها من الجِرَاح.
English: “He has no right to say that,” he replied, “since, if God’s Emissary did not issue any ruling about it at all, then it does not follow that he left all torts that are less than that uncompensated.”

Arabic: قال: وكذلك يقول لك: هو إذا لم يقل: لا تعقِل العاقلة ما دون الموضحة، فلم يحرِّم أن تعقل العاقلة ما دونها،
English: Someone could say to you: “If God’s Emissary did not say that the kin-group is not liable for what is less than such a wound, then he has not forbidden that the kin-group be liable for what is less than that.

Arabic: ولو قضى في الموضحة، ولم يقضِ فيما دونها على العاقلة ما منع ذلك العاقلةَ أن تَغرَم ما دونها،
English: If he had ruled that the kin-group was liable for such a wound, but had not ruled that it was liable for what was less than it, that would not have prevented the kin-group from incurring liability for what was less.”

Arabic: إذا غَرِمت الأكثرَ غرمت الأقلَّ، كما قلنا نحن وأنت، واحتججتَ على صاحبنا،
English: If they can incur liability for the greater amount, then they can incur it for the lesser amount, as both you and we have held, and as I have argued against our associate.

Arabic: ولو جاز هذا لك، جاز عليك.ولو قضى النبي بنصف العُشر على العاقلة: أن يقول قائل: تغرم نصف العشر والديةَ، ولا تغرم ما بينهما، ويكون ذلك في مال الجاني؟! ولكن هذا غيرُ جائز لأحد،
English: If it were admissible in your favor, it would also be admissible against you—even if the Prophet had ruled that the kin-group was liable for one-twentieth—that one say: “The kin-group is liable for onetwentieth of the blood-price, or the entire blood-price, but it has no liability for what lies between; that comes out of the tortfeasor’s assets.” But it is not permissible for anyone to say that.

Arabic: والقول فيه أن جميع ما كان خطأ فعلى العاقلة، وإن كان درهماً.
English: The opinion one should hold about that is that liability for all unintentional torts is that of the kin-group, even if it is only a dirham.

Arabic: وقلت له: قد قال بعض أصحابنا: إذا جنى الحر على العبد جنايةً فأتى على نفسه أو ما دونها خطأ، فهي في ماله دون [ص:537] عاقلته، ولا تعقل العاقلة عبداً،
English: I said to him: Some of our associates have held that if a free person commits an unintentional tort against a slave and kills him or inflicts a severe injury that does not lead to death, then compensation should be paid out of his own assets, not those of his kingroup, and that the kin-group should not be liable for torts against slaves.

Arabic: فقلنا: هي جناية حر، وإذ قضى رسول الله أن عاقلة الحر تحمل جنايته في حر إذا كانت غُرْماً لاحقاً بجناية خطأ، وكذلك جنايتُه في العبد إذا كانت غُرْماً من خطأ، والله أعلم،
English: We hold that it is a tort committed by a free person. Since God’s Emissary ruled that the free person’s kin-group bears liability for his tort against another free person, then it is a liability arising from his unintentional tort, and so, too, his tort against a slave is a liability arising from his unintentional tort, though God knows best.

Arabic: وقلتَ بقولنا فيه، وقلتَ: من قال لا تعقل العاقلة عبداً احتمل قوله لا تعقل جناية عبدٍ، لأنها في عنقه دون مال سيده غيرِه
English: You adopted our opinion and held that whoever says that the kingroup is not liable for the slave could mean that it is not liable for the tort committed by a slave because it is the personal liability of the slave, not payable from the assets of his owner, separately from the slave.

Arabic: فقلتَ بقولنا، ورأيتَ ما احتججتُ به من هذا حجةً صحيحةً داخلة في معنى السنة؟قال: أجل.
English: So you adopted our opinion and took the view that what we adduced as authority was valid and covered by the rationale found in Prophetic Practice. “Yes,” he replied.

Arabic: قال: وقلتُ له: وقال صاحبك وغيره من [ص:538] أصحابنا: جِرَاح العبد في ثمنه كجِرَاح الحر في ديته، ففي عينه نصفُ ثمنه، وفي موضحته نصفُ عشر ثمنه،
English: I said to him: Your associate and others among our associates hold that the tort against a slave is compensated relative to his price, just as the tort against a free person is compensated relative to his full blood-price. Loss of an eye is compensated with half his price, and a wound that lays bare the bone with one-twentieth of his price.

Arabic: وخالفْتَنَا فيه، فقلتَ: في جراح العبد ما نَقَصَ من ثمنه.
English: You disagree with us about this and say, “The tort against a slave is compensated relative to the actual diminution of his purchase price.”

Arabic: قال: فأنا أبدأ، فأسألك عن حجتك في قول جِرَاح العبد في ديته:
English: “Let me begin by asking you,” he said, “about the authority for your opinion that the tort against a slave is compensated relative to his purchase price, just as that for a free person is relative to his blood-price.

Arabic: أخبراً قلته أم قياساً؟قلت: أما الخبر فيه، فعن سعيد بن المسيب.قال: فاذكره؟
English: Do you hold this on the basis of a report or an analogy?” As for the report, I replied, it is from Saʿīd ibn al-Musayyab.“Cite it,” he requested.

Arabic: قلت: أخبرنا سفيان عن الزهري عن سعيد بن المسيب أنه قال: عَقْلُ العبد في ثمنه، فسمعته منه كثيراً هكذا، وربما قال: كجراح الحر في ديته،
English: Sufyān reported to us from al-Zuhrī, from Saʿīd ibn al-Musayyab, who said: “Tort compensation for a slave is relative to his price.” I heard this from him frequently in this form, and sometimes he added: “just as the tort against a free person is compensated relative to his blood-price.”

Arabic: سقطمنالنسخة
English: A trustworthy person reported to us—namely, Yaḥyā ibn Ḥassān—from al-Layth ibn Saʿd, from Saʿīd ibn al-Musayyab, who said: “The tort against a slave is compensated relative to his price just as the tort against a free person is compensated relative to his blood-price.”

Arabic: قال ابن شهاب: فإن ناساً يقولون: يُقَوَّم سلعةً.فقال: إنما سألتك خبراً تقوم به حجَّتُك.
English: Ibn Shihāb said that, according to some people, Saʿīd ibn alMusayyab added, “and he is assigned a value, like goods.” “I am asking you only for a report that provides binding authority,” he said.

Arabic: فقلت: قد أخبرتك أني لا أعرف فيه خبراً عن أحدٍ أعلى من سعيد بن المسيب.
English: I told you, I replied, that I do not know any reports about it from anyone further back than Saʿīd ibn al-Musayyab.

Arabic: قال: فليس في قوله حجة.قال: وما ادعيتُ ذلك فتردَّه عليّ!
English: “But his opinion does not constitute binding authority,” he said. I made no such claim, I replied, that you could refute.

Arabic: قال: فاذكر الحجة فيه؟قلت: قياساً على الجناية على الحر.
English: “Then cite some authority for it,” he demanded. I replied: It is based on an analogy with torts against free persons.

Arabic: قال: قد يفارق الحرَّ في أن دية الحر مؤقَّتة، [ص:540] وديتُه ثمنُهُ، فيكونُ بالسِّلَع من الإبل والدواب وغير ذلك أشبهَ، لأن في كل واحد منهما ثمنَه. ُ
English: “But the slave differs from a free person,” he said, “since the blood-price of the free person is a fixed amount, and the blood-price of the slave is his purchase price, so that he is closer in that regard to goods, such as camels, livestock, and other such things, since the compensation for destroying those things is their purchase price.”

Arabic: فقلت: فهذا حجة لمن قال: لا تعقل العاقلة ثمن العبد: عليك.قال: ومن أين؟
English: That argument supports the view of those who hold that the kin-group is not liable for the killing of a slave and thus works against you, I said. “How so?” he asked.

Arabic: قال: يقول لك: لمَ قلتَ تعقل العاقلة ثمن العبد إذا جنى عليه الحر قيمته، وهو عندك بمنزلة الثمن؟ ولو جنى على بعير جناية ضمِنها في ماله؟
English: I replied: Someone could ask you, “Why do you hold that the kingroup is liable for the purchase price of the slave if a free person commits a tort against the slave that damages him to the extent of his total value—for in your view, the compensation is the same as his price—yet if he committed a tort against a camel he would be liable for the damages out of his own assets?”

Arabic: قال: فهو نفسٌ محرمة.قلت: والبعير نفس محرمة على قاتله؟
English: “His life is inviolate,” he replied. Is not the camel’s life inviolate with respect to the one who tortiously kills it? I asked.

Arabic: قال: ليست كحرمة المؤمن.
English: “Not,” he said, “like the inviolability of a believer.”

Arabic: قلت: ويقول لك، ولا العبدُ كحرمة الحر في كل أمره.
English: Then, I replied, someone could object, “Neither is the slave, in his inviolability, like the free person in all respects.”

Arabic: [ص:541] فقلت: فهو عندك مجُاَمِعُ الحرِّ في المعنى،
English: So in your view, I said, he has that same point in common with the free person.

Arabic: أفتعقله العاقلة؟قال: ونعم.قلت: وحَكَمَ الله في المؤمن يُقتل خطأً بديةٍ وتحريرِ رقبة؟قال: نعم.
English: Is the kin-group liable for him, then? “Yes.” Did God not rule, I continued, that for the believer who is killed unintentionally one pays the full blood-price and frees a slave? “Yes.”

Arabic: قلت: وزعمتَ أن في العبد تحريرَ رقبةٍ كهي في الحر وثمنً، وأن الثمن كالدية؟قال: نعم.
English: And you claim, I continued, that for the slave who is killed unintentionally, one frees a slave, just as in the case of the free person, and pays his purchase price, and that his purchase price is like the blood-price? “Yes.”

Arabic: قلت: وزعمتَ أنك تقتل الحرَّ بالعبد؟قال: نعم.
English: And you also claim that a free person can be killed in retaliation for the death of a slave? “Yes,” he replied.

Arabic: [ص:542] قلت: وزعمنا أنا نقتل العبدَ بالعبد؟قال: وأنا أقوله.
English: And we both claim, I said, that we should kill a slave in retaliation for a slave? “I so hold as well,” he said.

Arabic: قلت: فقد جامَعَ الحرَّ في هذه المعاني عندنا وعندك، في أن بينه وبين المملوك قصاصاً في كل جُرح، وجامَعَ البعير في معنى أن ديتَه ثمنُهُ،
English: I said: The free person shares in all these considerations, in both our view and yours, in regard to retaliation for injuries, but a slave has in common with the camel the fact that his blood-price is equivalent to his purchase price.

Arabic: فكيف اخترتَ في جراحته أن تجعلها كجراحة بعيرٍ، فتجعل فيه ما نَقَصَه، ولم تجعل جراحته في ثمنه كجراح الحر في ديته؟ وهو يجُامع الحر في خمسة معاني، ويفارقه في معنى واحد؟
English: So how did you elect, in the case of an injury to him, to make it like the injuring of a camel, making damages for an injury to him equivalent to the extent to which his value is diminished, but not making the injury to the camel be compensated relative to its full price, just as the injury of a free person is compensated relative to his blood-price—even though the slave has five points in common with a free person and is only distinguishable from him in one respect?

Arabic: أليس أن تقيسه على ما يجامعه في خمسة معاني أولى بك من أن تقيسه على جامعه على معنى واحد؟!
English: Is it not more appropriate for you to base the analogy on the thing with which he has five points in common rather than on the thing with which he has only one?

Arabic: مع أنه يجُامع الحر في أكثرَ من هذا: أن ما حُرم على الحر حُرم عليه، وأن عليه الحدودَ والصلاةَ والصوم وغيرها من الفرائض، وليس من البهائم بسبيل!!
English: But in fact the slave has even more in common with the free person: whatever is unlawful for a free person to do is unlawful for a slave, and the slave is, in addition, subject to penal sanctions, prayers, fasting, and other obligations, and there is thus no way at all in which he is like a dumb animal.

Arabic: قال: رأيتُ ديتَه ثمنَه؟
English: “Do you,” he asked, “consider his blood-price to be his purchase price?”

Arabic: [ص:543] قلت: وقد رأيتَ دية المرأة نصف دية الرجل، فما منع ذلك جراحَهَا أن تكون في ديتها، كما كانت جراح الرجل في ديته؟!
English: I view the blood-price for a woman as half that of a man, I said, but that does not prevent compensation for an injury to her from being calculated relative to her full blood-price, just as it is in the case of a man.

Arabic: وقلت له: إذا كانت الدية في ثلاث سنين إبلاً أفليس قد زعمتَ أن الإبل لا تكون بصفة دَيناً؟
English: I said to him: If the blood-price is to paid in the form of camels over three years, in thirds, then have you not claimed that the camels are tantamount to something purchased based merely on the seller’s description, and thus a debt?

Arabic: فكيف أنكرت أن تُشترى الإبل بصفة إلى أجل؟ ولم تقيسه على الدية، ولا على الكتابة ولا، على المهر، وأنت تجيز في هذا كله أن تكون الإبل بصفة دَيناً؟!
English: How can you object to a sale of camels, based merely on a description, with the payment for the camels being a debt, and not base the analogy for it on payment of the blood-price, an installment contract for manumission, or a dowry? Yet, in all these cases, you allow the sale of camels, based merely on the seller’s description, to become a debt?

Arabic: فخالفت فيه القياس، وخالفتَ الحديث نصاً عن النبي: أنه استسلف بعيراً، ثم أمر بقضائه بعد؟!
English: You have gone against the dictates of analogy and against the explicitly worded hadith-report from the Prophet that he once accepted advance payment for some camels and ordered that his end of the bargain be fulfilled at a later time.

Arabic: [ص:544] قال: كرهه ابن مسعود.
English: “Ibn Masʿūd disapproved of that,” he said.

Arabic: فقلنا: وفي أحد مع النبي حجة؟!قال: لا، إن ثبت عن النبي.
English: Does binding authority come from anyone but the Prophet? I asked. “No,” he replied, “if it is confirmed as coming from the Prophet.”

Arabic: قلت: هو ثابت باستسلافه بعيراً وقضاه خيراً منه،
English: It is in fact confirmed, I retorted, by a case in which the Prophet accepted advance payment for camels and fulfilled his end of the contract by delivering camels that were better than what was called for.

Arabic: وثابت في الديات عندنا وعندك، هذا في معنى السنة.
English: It is also confirmed in regard to blood-price payments, in our view and in yours, as covered by the rationale found in Prophetic Practice.

Arabic: قال: فما الخبر الذي يقاس عليه؟
English: “What,” he asked, “is the report on which one bases the analogy?”

Arabic: قلت: أخبرنا مالك عن زيد بن أسلم عن عطاء بن يسار عن أبي رافع: ” أن النبي استسلف من رجل بعيراً فجاءته إبل، فأمرني أن أقضيه إياه، فقلت: لا أجد في الإبل إلا جملاً خِياراً، فقال: أعطه إياه، فإن خيار الناس أحسنهم قضاءً “
English: I said: Mālik reported to us from Zayd ibn Aslam, from ʿAṭāʾ ibn Yasār, from Abū Rāfiʿ: “The Prophet once accepted advance payment from someone for camels. Some camels were brought to him and the Prophet ordered me to fulfill his end of the contract with them. ‘I can only find choice camels among these,’ I said. ‘Then give those to him,’ he said, ‘for the best people are those who are best at paying their debts.’” . . .

Arabic: قال: فما الخبر الذي لا يقاس عليه؟
English: “What kind of report cannot be the basis for an analogy?” he asked.

Arabic: قلت: ما كان لله فيه حكمٌ منصوص، ثم كانت لرسول الله سنة بتخفيفٍ في بعض الفرض دون بعض:
English: One that involves a textually explicit rule of God’s, I replied, in regard to which God’s Emissary has a practice that lightens some parts of the obligation but not others.

Arabic: عُمِلَ بالرخصة فيما رخَّص فيه رسول الله دون ما سواها، ولم يُقَس ما سواها عليها،
English: One acts in accordance with the dispensation to the extent of God’s Emissary’s dispensation, but not in regard to other things, and one cannot draw analogies from such dispensations to other things.

Arabic: وهكذا ما كان لرسول الله من حكم عام بشيء، ثم سَن سنة تفارق حكم العام.
English: So, too, for anything for which God’s Emissary has an unrestricted rule and then institutes a practice in regard to that same matter that differs from that unrestricted rule.

Arabic: قال: وفي مثل ماذا؟ قلت: فرض الله الوضوء على من قام إلى الصلاة من نومه، فقال: {إذا قمتم إلى الصلاةِ، فاغسلوا وجوهكم، وأيديكم إلى المرافق، وامسحوا برؤسكم وأرجلَكم إلى الكعبين} [المائدة 6]
English: “Such as?” he asked. God imposed the obligation to perform ablutions on whoever rises to pray after sleeping, I said. God said: «When you rise to pray, wash your faces and your hands up to the elbows, and wipe your heads and wash your feet up to the ankles.»

Arabic: فقصد قصْد الرجلين بالفرض، كما قَصَدَ قصْد ما سواهما في أعضاء الوضوء.
English: He made this obligation pertain to the two feet, just as He made it pertain to the other limbs that require ablutions.

Arabic: [ص:546] فلما مسح رسول الله على الخفين لم يكن لنا – والله أعلم – أن نمسح على عمامة، ولا بُرْفُع، ولا قُفَّازين: قياساً عليهما،
English: But when God’s Emissary wiped his footwear, it was not for us, though God knows best, to wipe a turban, a veil, or a glove, on the basis of an analogy to the footwear.

Arabic: وأثبتنا الفرض في أعضاء الوضوء كلها، وأرخصْنا بمسح النبي في المسح على الخفين، دون ما سواهما.
English: We confirmed the obligation in regard to all the limbs that receive ablutions, and we recognized a dispensation for wiping the footwear, based on the Prophet’s practice of wiping, but not for anything else.

Arabic: قال: فتعدُّ هذا خلافاً للقُرَآن؟قلت: لا تخالف سنة لرسول الله كتاب الله بحال.
English: “Do you consider that to be contrary to the Qurʾan?” he asked.Under no circumstances, I replied, does a practice of God’s Emissary contradict the Book of God.

Arabic: قال: فما معنى هذا عندك؟
English: “Then what is the meaning in this case?” he asked.

Arabic: قلت: معناه أن يكون قَصَدَ بفرض إمساس القدمين الماءَ مَن لا خُفَّي عليه لَبِسَهما كاملَ الطهارة.
English: The meaning, I said, is that the obligation to bring the feet into contact with water is directed at those who are not wearing footwear that they put on in a state of complete ritual purity.

Arabic: قال: أوَ يجوز هذا في اللسان؟
English: “Is that a permissible linguistic usage?” he asked.

Arabic: قلت: نعم، كما جاز أن يقوم إلى الصلاة من هو [ص:547] على وضوء، فلا يكون المراد بالوضوء، استدلالاً بأن رسول الله صلى صلاتين وصلوات بوضوء واحد.
English: Yes, I answered, just as it is permissible for someone to rise to pray whose ablutions are still effective for him and not be intended by the obligation to perform ablutions. That is based on an inference from the fact that God’s Emissary prayed two or more prayers having performed ablutions only once.

Arabic: وقال الله: {والسارقُ والسارقةُ، فاقطعوا أيديَهما جزاءً بما كسبا نَكالاً من الله، والله عزيز حكيم} [المائدة 38]فدلت السنة على أن الله لم يرد بالقطع كل السارقين.
فكذلك دلت سنة رسول الله بالمسح أنه قصد بالفرض في غسل القدمين من لا خُفَّي عليه لبسهما كاملَ الطهارة.
English: Similarly, the Practice of God’s Emissary indicated, in regard to wiping the feet during ablutions, that the obligation to wash the feet pertained to someone who had not donned footwear while in a state of complete ritual purity.

Arabic: قال: فما مثلُ هذا في السنة؟قلت: نهى رسول الله عن بيع التمر بالتمر إلا مِثْلاً بمثل
English: “What else in accounts of Prophetic Practice,” he asked, “is like this?” God’s Emissary prohibited the sale of dried dates for dried dates except in like amounts.

Arabic: “وسئل عن الرُّطَب بالتمر؟ فقال: أينقص الرُّطَب إذا يبس؟ فقيل: نعم، فنهى عنه”.
English: He was asked about the sale of ripe dates for dried dates and he asked, “Do the ripe dates weigh less after they are dried?” “Yes,” it was replied. So he prohibited that.

Arabic: و ” نهى عن المزابنة “، وهي كل ما عُرِف كيلُه منه، وهذا كله مجتَمِع المعاني،
English: He also prohibited the muzābanah-sale, which is any time that something susceptible to usury and whose volume is known is exchanged for something of the same type but of an unmeasured amount whose volume is unknown. These all have several points in common.

Arabic: “ورخص أن تُبَاع العرايا بخَرْصها تمراً يأكلها أهلها رُطَبَاً”
English: The Prophet also gave a dispensation for the ʿarāyā-sale, that is, the sale of dates on the tree in an unknown quantity for dried dates that the people who only had dates on the tree could eat.

Arabic: [ص:548] فرخَّصنا في العرايا بإرخاصه، وهي بيع الرطب بالتمر، وداخلةٌ في المزابنة بإرخاصه،
English: So we recognized a dispensation for the ʿarāyā-sale, which is the sale of dates on the tree for dried dates, and which would otherwise belong in the same category as the muzābanah-sale, because of the dispensation he granted.

Arabic: فأثبتنا التحريم محرماً عاماً في كل شيء من صنف واحد مأكول، بعضُهُ جُزَاف وبعضه بكيل: للمزابنة، وأحللنا العرايا خاصة بإحلاله من الجملة التي حَرَّم،
English: Thus, we affirmed that the prohibition against any sale of food commodities of one type, in which an unknown amount is exchanged for a known volume, be applied unrestrictedly, because of the Prophet’s ruling on the muzābanah-sale, but we made the ʿarāyā-sale lawful, as a restriction thereupon, because the Prophet made it lawful, by excepting it from the general category of what he made unlawful.

Arabic: ولم نبطل أحد الخبرين بالآخر، ولم نجعله قياساً عليه.
English: We do not use one of the two reports to invalidate the other, nor did we use the one as the basis for an analogy.

Arabic: قال: فما وجه هذا؟
English: “What is the reason in this case?” he asked.

Arabic: قلت: يحتمل وجهين: أولاهما به عندي – والله أعلم – أن يكون ما نهى عنه جملةً أراد به ما سوى العرايا،
English: There are two possible reasons, I replied. The better one, in my view, though God knows best, is that by what he prohibited in general terms he intended to include everything other than the ʿarāyā-sale.

Arabic: ويحتمل أن يكون أَرْخص فيها بعد وجوبها في جملة النهي،
English: It is also possible that he provided a dispensation for it after the prohibition of the general category to which it belonged had become mandatory.

Arabic: وأيَّهما كان فعلينا طاعته بإحلال ما أحل، وتحريم ما حَرَّم.
English: Whichever of the two is the case, it is incumbent on us to obey him, by holding lawful what he made lawful and holding unlawful what he made unlawful.

Arabic: وقضى رسول الله بالدية في الحر المسلم يُقتل خطأ مائة من الإبل، وقضى بها على العاقلة.
English: . . .God’s Emissary ruled in regard to the blood-price that the unintentional killing of a free Muslim was to be compensated by one hundred camels, and he further ruled that this was imposed on the kingroup.

Arabic: وكان العمد يخالف الخطأ في القَوَد والمأثَم، ويوافقه في أنه قد تكون فيه دية.
English: Intentional killing differs from unintentional killing because it incurs retaliation and is also a sin, but resembles it in that it could also involve the blood-price.

Arabic: فلما كان قضاء رسول الله في كل امرئ فيما لزمه، إنما هو في ماله دون مال غيره، إلا في الحر يُقتل خطأ:
English: When God’s Emissary held that, in regard to all those who were potentially liable, payment was to be made from their assets and not from others’ assets, except in the case of the free person killed unintentionally, we, too, held that the kin-group was liable for the unintentional killing of a free person just as God’s Emissary ruled: everyone who is potentially liable must pay from his own assets, not others’ assets, except for the unintentional killing of a free person.

Arabic: قضينا على العاقلة في الحر يُقتل خطأ ما قضى به رسول الله، وجعلنا الحر يُقتل عمدا إذا كانت فيه دية: في مال الجاني، كما كان كل ما جنى في ماله غيرَ الخطأ،
English: We assessed liability for the intentional killing of a free person, where the blood-price was applicable, against the assets of the perpetrator, just as compensation for any intentional tort that he might commit would come from his own assets, though not in the case of unintentional torts.

Arabic: ولم نقس ما لزمه من غُرْم بغير جراح خطأٍ على ما لزمه بقتل الخطأ.
English: We did not analogize from his liability in cases of unintentional killing to the liability he incurs in cases other than unintentional injuries.

Arabic: فإن قال قائل: ما الذي يَغرم الرجلُ من جنايته، وما لَزِمَه غيرُ الخطأ؟
English: If someone were to ask, “What compensation does someone owe for an intentional tort, and what is his liability for an unintentional tort?”

Arabic: [ص:550] قلت: قال الله: {وآتوا النساءَ صَدُقَاتهنَّ نِحْلةً} [النساء 4]وقال: {وأقيموا الصلاةَ وآتوا الزكاةَ} [البقرة 43]وقال: {فإن أُحْصِرتم فما استيسرَ من الهَدْي} [البقرة 196]
English: I would reply: God said: «Give the women their dowries as a free gift» and «Perform prayer and pay alms» and «But if you are prevented, give whatever offerings are feasible.»

Arabic: وقال: {والذين يُظاهرون من نسائهم، ثم يعودون لما قالوا، فتحريرُ رَقَبَةٍ من قبل أن يَتَمَاسّا} [المجادلة 3]وقال: {ومَن قَتَلَه منكم مُتَعَمِّداً فَجَزَاءٌ مِثلُ ما قتل من النَّعَم يحكُمُ به ذَوَا عدْلٍ منكم هَدْياً بالغَ الكعبةِ، أو كفَّارةٌ طعامُ مساكين، أو عَدْلُ ذلك صياماً ليذوقَ وبالَ أمرِه، عفا الله عما سَلَفَ، ومَن عاد فينتقمُ الله منه، والله عزيز ذو انتقام} [المائدة 95]
English: He also said: «Those who make their wives like their mothers’ backs and then return to what they have sworn not to do: the penalty is the freeing of a slave before they touch each other» and «If any of you kill such game intentionally, there must be recompense—the like of what he has killed from his livestock, as two just men from you decide, an offering to reach the Kaaba or expiation: food for the destitute or the equivalent of that in fasting, that he may taste the mischief of his action. God forgives what has happened in the past; but God will take vengeance on those who repeat the offense»

Arabic: [ص:551] وقال: {فكفَّارتُه إطعامُ عَشَرَةِ مساكينَ من أوسط ما تُطعمون أهليكم، أو كِسوتهم أو تحريرُ رقبة، فمن لم يجدْ فصيامُ ثلاثةِ أيام} [المائدة 89]
English: and «Expiation for a broken oath is the feeding of ten destitute people with the average of the food with which you feed your families or the clothing of them or the freeing of a slave. Whoever does not find the means for that should fast for three days.»

Arabic: وقضى رسول الله على ” أن على أهل الأموال حِفظَهَا بالنهار، وما أفسَدَت المواشي بالليل، فهو ضامن على أهلها” .
English: God’s Emissary ruled: “People are responsible for taking care of their own property during the day, but what livestock destroy at night is the liability of their owner.”

Arabic: فدل الكتاب والسنة وما لم يختلف المسلمون فيه: أن هذا كله في مال الرجل، بحقٍّ وجب عليه لله، أو أوجبه الله عليه للآدميين، بوجوهٍ لَزِمَته، وأنه لا يُكَلف أحدٌ غُرْمَه عنه.
English: The Book, Prophetic Practice, and that about which Muslims do not disagree all indicate that these things are to be taken from a man’s property by virtue of a claim that becomes due against him, either in God’s favor or in favor of human beings, however such a claim may arise. No one else, moreover, is liable for such a debt on that person’s behalf.

Arabic: ولا يجوز أن يجني رجل، ويَغرم غير الجاني، إلا في الموضع الذي سَنَّه رسول الله فيه خاصة من قتل الخطأ وجنايته على الآدميين خطأً.
English: With regard to the commission of a tort, no one but the actual tortfeasor may bear financial responsibility for it except in the situation for which God’s Emissary has established a practice that is applied restrictively, where there is an unintentional killing, or an unintentional injury against other persons.

Arabic: [ص:552] والقياس فيما جنى على بهيمة أو متاع أو غيره – على ما وصفت -: أن ذلك في ماله،
English: Analogical reasoning dictates—in regard to torts against livestock, property, and other things—that compensation be paid, as I have explained, out of the tortfeasor’s assets.

Arabic: لأن الأكثر المعروفَ أن ما جنى في ماله،
English: This is because, as is well known, in the majority of cases one satisfies one’s liability out of one’s own assets.

Arabic: فلا يقاس على الأقل، ويُترك الأكثر المعقول،
English: One does not analogize from the minority of cases while ignoring the rule suggested by reason in the majority of cases.

Arabic: ويُخَص الرجل الحر يَقتل الحرَّ الخطأ، فتعقله العاقلة، وما كان من جناية خطأً على نفس وجُرح: خبراً وقياساً.
English: The free man who unintentionally kills another free person is a restricted case: the kin-group is liable for compensation in that case and for any other unintentional injuries involving life or limbs.This rule is based on both reports and analogical reasoning.

Arabic: وقضى رسول الله في الجنين بغُرَّة عبد أو أمة، وقَوَّم أهلُ العلم الغرة خمساً من الإبل.
English: For the death of a fetus, God’s Emissary held that a choice male or female slave be paid in compensation, and scholars valued such a slave at five camels.

Arabic: قال: فلما لم يُحكَا أن رسول الله سأل عن الجنين: أَذَكَر هو أم أنثى؟ إذ قضى فيه سَوَّى بين الذكر والأنثى[ص:553] إذا سقط ميتا،
English: Because it was not related that God’s Emissary asked whether the fetus was male or female at the time he ruled, he must have made the male and female equal if the fetus was stillborn.

Arabic: ولو سقط حياً فمات جَعَلوا في الرجل مائة من الإبل، وفي المرأة خمسين.
English: If it was born alive and then died, then the scholars determined liability at one hundred camels for a male and fifty for a female.

Arabic: فلم يجز أن يقاس على الجنين شيء من قِبَل أن الجنايات على من عُرِفَت جنايته مُوَقَّتاتٌ معروفات. مفروقٌ فيها بين الذكر والأنثى.
English: Thus, it is not permissible to base an analogy on the case of the fetus at all, because tort liability is imposed in cases where the tort is known, with fixed, well-known compensation, which is differentiated depending on whether the victim is male or female.

Arabic: وأن لا يختلف الناس في أن لو سقط الجنين حياً، ثم مات كانت فيه دية كاملة، إن كان ذكراً فمائةٌ من الإبل، وإن كانت أنثى فخمسون من الإبل،
English: People do not disagree that if the fetus emerges alive and then dies, that the full blood-price is payable. If it is male, then one hundred camels, and if female, then fifty camels.

Arabic: وأن المسلمين – فيما علمت – لا يختلفون أن رجلاً لو قَطَعَ الموتى لم يكن في واحد منهم دِيَة، ولا أرْش، والجنينُ لا يعدو أن يكون حياً أو ميتاً.
English: Muslims do not disagree, as far as I know, that if a man mutilates corpses, no blood-price is due for any of them, and no lesser damages either. The fetus can only be either dead or alive.

Arabic: فلما حكم فيه رسول الله بحكمٍ فارق حكم النفوس، الأحياءِ والأمواتِ، وكان مغيَّبَ الأمر: كان الحكمُ بما حَكَمَ به على الناس اتباعاً لأمر رسول الله.
English: So when God’s Emissary ruled about it in a way that differed from the rulings concerning live and dead persons, in the situation where its state was unknowable, the ruling that he issued was one that people were obliged to follow simply because it was a command of God’s Emissary.

Arabic: [ص:554] قال فهل تعرف له وجهاً؟قلت: وجهاً واحداً، والله أعلم.قال: وما هو؟قلت: يقال: إذا لم تُعرف له حياة، وكان لا يُصلى عليه، ولا يرث: فالحكمُ فيه أنها جناية على أمه،
English: “Do you know any reason for this?” he asked. One reason, I replied, though God knows best. “What is it?” It is said that if you do not know whether it was ever alive, such that funeral prayers would have been said over it, and it would have inherited, then the ruling is that it is a tort against its mother.

Arabic: وقَّت فيها رسول الله شيئاً قوَّمه المسلمون، كما وقَّت في الموضِحة.
English: God’s Emissary fixed some compensation for that injury to which Muslims assigned a value, just as he did for a serious wound that lays bare the bone.

Arabic: قال: فهذا وجه.قلت: وجهٌ لا يُبين الحديثُ أنه حَكَمَ به له، فلا يصح أن يقال: إنه حكم به له،
English: “That is a reason,” he said. A reason, I said, that the hadith-report itself does not explain as being the basis for his ruling, so it is not valid to say that it was.

Arabic: ومن قال: إنه حكم به لهذا المعنى قال: هو للمرأة دون الرجل، هو للأم دون أبيه، لأنه عليها جُنِي،
English: Whoever so claims holds that compensation should be paid to the woman, not to the man, to the mother, not to the father, because the tort was committed against her.

Arabic: ولا حكم للجنين يكون به موروثاً، ولا يُورَث مَن لا يَرِث.قال: فهذا قول صحيح؟[ص:555] قلت: الله أعلم.
English: No ruling can be made suggesting that the fetus has heirs, since whoever cannot inherit cannot have heirs. “Is that opinion right?” he asked. God knows best, I replied.

Arabic: قال: فإن لم يكن هذا وجهَه، فما يقال لهذا الحكم؟قلنا: يقال له: سنةٌ تُعُبِّد العبادُ بأن يحكموا بها.
English: “If that is not a good reason, then what does one say about this ruling?” he asked. One should say, we replied, that it is a Prophetic practice that God’s servants are obligated to use for their rulings.

Arabic: وما يقال لغيره مما يدل الخبر على المعنى الذي له حُكم به؟
English: “But what should one say in the case of other rulings where the report indicates the reason that the ruling was made?” he asked.

Arabic: قيل: حُكْمُ سنة تُعُبِّدوا بها لأمر عرفوه بمعنى الذي تُعُبِّدوا له في السنة، فقاسوا عليه ما كان في مثل معناه.
English: One says, I answered, that it is the ruling from a Prophetic practice that they are obligated to observe because of a rationale that they know is the reason why they are obligated to observe it—as part of Prophetic Practice. They can then, in turn, base an analogy on it for cases in which a similar rationale is operative.

Arabic: قال: فاذكر منه وجهاً غيرَ هذا إن حضرك تجمع فيه ما يقاس عليه، ولا يقاس؟
English: “Mention another case,” he requested, “different from this, if you have one that includes something one can use as a basis for an analogy and something that may not be so used.”

Arabic: فقلت له: قضى رسول الله في المُصَرَّاة من الإبل والغنم إذا حَلَبَها مشتريها: ” إن أحبَّ أمسكها، وإن أحب ردَّها وصاعاً من تمر” ، وقضى ” أن الخراج بالضمان” فكان معقولاً في ” الخراج بالضمان ” أني إذا ابتعت عبداً فأخذت له خَرَاجاً ثم ظهرْتُ منه على عيب يكونُ لي ردُّه: فما أخذت من الخراج والعبدُ في مِلْكي ففيه خصلتان:
English: So I said to him: God’s Emissary ruled, concerning camels and sheep with full udders, that if the buyer milks them, then “if he chooses to, he may keep the animal; or, he may return it together with a ṣāʿ-measure of dates.” He also ruled that “profit is retained because of liability for risk of loss.” It accords with reason that the retention of profit is in exchange for bearing the risk of loss—how could it not be? If I purchase a slave and make a profit because of him, then I become aware of a defect that allows me to return him, the profit I earn while I own the slave has two characteristics.

Arabic: إحداهما: أنه لم يكن في ملك البائع، ولم يكن له حصة من الثمن،
English: One is that it is not owned by the seller, and no portion of the purchase price is allocated to it.

Arabic: والأخرى: أنها في ملكي، وفي الوقت الذي خرج فيه العبد من ضمان بائعه إلى ضماني،
English: The other is that it came into being while the slave was in my possession, when the slave was transferred from the liability of his seller to my liability.

Arabic: فكان العبد لو مات مات من مالي وفي ملكي،
English: If that slave dies, he will have died as part of my property, and subject to my ownership.

Arabic: ولو شئتُ حبسته بعيبه، فكذلك الخراج.
English: If I wished, I could retain him with the defect—and the profit as well.

Arabic: فقلنا بالقياس على حديث “الخراج بالضمان ” فقلنا: كل ما خرج من ثمرِ حائطٍ اشتريته، أو وَلَدِ ماشيةٍ أو جاريةٍ اشتريتها، فهو مثل الخراج، لأنه حدث في مِلك مشتريه، لا في ملك بائعه.
English: Our ruling is based on an analogy from the hadith-report “Profit is retained because of liability for risk of loss.” Anything that emanates from a walled orchard that I buy, or offspring from livestock, or the child from a female slave, is like the profit, because it comes into being as part of the property of its buyer, not as part of the property of its seller.

Arabic: وقلنا في المُصَرَّاة اتباعاً لأمر رسول الله، ولم نقس عليه،
English: But in regard to the animal with the full udder, our opinion follows the command of God’s Emissary, and we do not use that command as a basis for an analogy.

Arabic: وذلك أن الصفقة وقعت على شاة بعينها، فيها لبنٌ محبوس مغيَّب المعنى والقيمة،
English: That is because the bargain was made for the ewe in question, in which there was pent-up milk of unknowable character and value.

Arabic: ونحن نحيط أن لبن الإبل والغنم يختلف، وألبانُ كل واحد منهما يختلف،
English: We know with certainty that the milk of camels and sheep differs and that the milk of each individual one of those differs, as well.

Arabic: فلما قضى فيه رسول الله بشيء مؤقَّت، وهو صاعٌ من تمر: قلنا به اتباعاً لأمر رسول الله.
English: So when God’s Emissary ruled that a defined amount be paid in compensation—a ṣāʿmeasure of dates—we adopted that opinion, following the command of God’s Emissary.

Arabic: قال: فلو اشترى رجل شاة مُصَرَّاة، فَحَلَبها ثم رَضِيَهَا بعد العلم بعيب التصْرِيَة، فأمسكها شهراً حَلَبَها، ثم ظهر منها على عيب دلَّسه له البائعُ غيرِ التصرية: كان له ردُّها، وكان له اللبنُ بغير شيء،
English: If someone bought a ewe with a full udder, milked it, and then approved of it even after becoming aware of the defect of the pentup milk in its udder, and then kept it for a month and milked it again, and then there appeared a defect that had been concealed by the seller, apart from the full udder, he would be entitled to return it and the milk would be his, without any compensation.

Arabic: بمنزلة الخراج، لأنه لم يقع عليه صفقةُ البيع،
English: It would be in the nature of subsequently arising profit, since it was not the subject of the bargain.

Arabic: وإنما هو حادث في مِلك المشتري،
English: Rather, it comes into being as part of the buyer’s property.

Arabic: وكان عليه أن يرد فيما أخذ من لبن التَّصْرية صاعاً من تمر، كما قضى به رسول الله.
English: It would, however, be incumbent on him to return a ṣāʿ-measure of dates for the milk he got if he returned the animal because of the full udder, just as God’s Emissary ruled.

Arabic: فنكونُ قد قلنا في لبن التصرية خبراً، وفي اللبن بعد التصرية قياساً على ” الخراج بالضمان” ولبنُ التصرية مفارقٌ لِلَّبن الحادثِ بعده، لأنه وقعت عليه صفقةُ البيع، واللبنُ بعده حادث في ملك المشتري، لم تقع عليه صفقة البيع.
English: Thus, our opinion about the milk in the full udder is based on a report, and our opinion about the milk that subsequently comes into being is based on an analogy from the hadith-report “Profit is retained because of liability for risk of loss.” The milk in the full udder at the time of sale is distinguishable from the milk that subsequently comes into being because it formed a part of the bargain, whereas the milk that appears later in time came into being as part of the buyer’s property and was not the subject of the bargain.

Arabic: فإن قال قائل: ويكون أمرٌ واحدٌ يؤخذ من وجهين؟ قيل له: نعم، إذا جمَعَ أمرين مختلفين، أو أموراً مختلفة.
English: If someone were to ask, “Is this one matter that can be understood to have two different implications?” one should reply: Yes, since it combines two, or even several, different implications.

Arabic: فإن قال: فَمَثِّل من ذلك شيئاً غيرَ هذا؟ قلت: المرأة تبلغها وفاة زوجها،
English: If he asks, “Can you give me a different example of that?” I would say: A woman is informed that her husband has died.

Arabic: فتعتد، ثم تتزوج، ويدخل بها الزوج، لها الصَّدَاق، وعليها العِدَّة والولد لاحق، ولا حَدَّ على واحد منهما،
English: She fulfills the waiting period and then remarries. The new husband consummates the marriage, and then the first husband reappears alive: she becomes entitled to the dowry, is subject to the waiting period, any children born to them are the father’s, and neither is subject to penal sanction.

Arabic: ويُفَرَّق بينهما، ولا يتوارثان، وتكون الفُرقة فَسخاً بلا طَلاق.
English: They are then legally separated and do not inherit from each other, and the separation is an annulment of the marriage, not a divorce.

Arabic: يُحكم له إذا كان ظاهره حلالاً حكمَ الجلال، في ثبوت الصداق والعدة ولحُوق الولد ودَرءِ الحد،
English: Because the second marriage was lawful according to appearances, one rules regarding this marriage as one does regarding an ordinary lawful marriage: there is a dowry, a waiting period, a child that is the legitimate offspring of the father, and any penal sanction is averted.

Arabic: وحُكِم عليه إذ كان حراماً في الباطن حُكم الحرام في أن لا يُقَرَّا عليه، ولا تحل له إصابتُها بذلك النكاح إذا علما به، ولا يتوارثان،
English: However, according to the true state of affairs, one rules regarding it as one does for an unlawful marriage: the marriage is ended, it becomes unlawful for him to have sexual intercourse with her once they know that the first husband is alive, and they may not inherit from each other as spouses otherwise would.

Arabic: ولا يكون الفسخُ طلاقاً، لأنها ليست بزوجة.
English: The voiding of the contract is not a divorce, since she was never legally a spouse.

Arabic: ولهذا أشباهٌ، مثلُ المرأة تَنكح في عدتها.
English: There are many similar instances, like that of a woman who marries during her waiting period.

Arabic: [باب الاختلاف]
English: Chapter on Legal Disagreement

Arabic: قال: فإني أجد أهل العم قديماً وحديثاً مختلفين في بعض أمورهم، فهل يسعهم ذلك؟
English: “I find scholars now and in the past disagreeing about various matters. Are they allowed to do that?” he asked.

Arabic: قال: فقلت له: الاختلاف من وجهين: أحدهما: محرم، ولا أقول ذلك في الآخر.
English: Legal disagreement, I replied, is of two types. One is forbidden, but I do not say that about the other.

Arabic: قال: فما الاختلاف المحرم؟
English: “What is the forbidden kind of legal disagreement?”

Arabic: قلت: كل ما أقام الله به الحجة في كتابه أو على لسان نبيه منصوصاً بيناً: لم يحل الاختلاف فيه لمن علمه.
English: I said: It is unlawful, for those who know of it, to disagree about any text that God used to furnish binding authority in a clear and textually explicit manner, whether in His Book or through the words of His Prophet.

Arabic: وما كان من ذلك يحتمل التأويل، ويُدرك قياساً، فذهب المتأول أو القايس إلى معنى يحتمله الخبر أو القياس، وإن خالفه فيه غيره: لم أقل أنه يُضَيَّق عليه ضِيقَ الخلاق في المنصوص.
English: When such things are susceptible to speculative interpretation, however, or arrived at by analogy—and the interpreter or person who analogizes arrives at a meaning that is plausible for the report or analogy in question, even if others disagree with him—I do not hold that he should be dissuaded from that as he should be if he holds an opinion contrary to a textually explicit passage.

Arabic: قال: فهل في هذا حجة تُبَين فرقك بين الاختلافين؟
English: “Can you cite some authority,” he asked, “that clarifies how you distinguished between the two kinds of legal disagreement?”

Arabic: قلت: قال الله في ذم التفرق: {وما تَفَرَّق الذين أوتوا الكتابَ إلا من بعد ما جاءتهم البينةُ} [البينة 4] وقال جل ثناؤه: {ولا تكونوا كالذين تَفَرقوا واختلفوا من بعد ما جاءهم البينات} [آل عمران 105] فَذَمَّ الاختلاف فيما جاءتهم به البينات.
English: Concerning the censure of division, I replied, God said, «Those who were given the Book became divided only after clear proof came to them» and he also said (sublime His praise) «Do not be like those who have become divided and disagreed after the clear proofs have come to them.» He censured disagreement about the clear proofs conveyed to them.

Arabic: فأما ما كُلِّفوا فيه الاجتهاد، فقد مَثَّلته لك بالقبلة والشهادة وغيرها.
English: As for those instances in which they are legally obligated to engage in legal interpretation, I have given you the examples of finding the prayer-direction, evaluating witnesses’ testimony, and other instances.

Arabic: قال: فَمَثِّل لي بعض ما افترق عليه من رُوي قوله من السلف، مما لله فيه نصُّ حكم يحتمل التأويل، فهل يوجد على الصواب فيه دلالة؟
English: “Give me some examples,” he requested, “of things over which those early Muslims whose opinions are transmitted disagreed, in instances where God has a textually explicit ruling that is subject to speculative interpretation. Is there an indication of the correct answer in such a case?”

Arabic: قلت: قَلَّ ما اختلفوا فيه إلا وجدنا فيه عندنا دِلالة من كتاب الله أو سنة رسوله، أو قياساً عليهما، أو على واحد منهما.
English: Only rarely, I replied, did they disagree about anything without our finding something that we considered an indication from the Book of God, the Practice of God’s Emissary, or an analogy based on one or both of them.

Arabic: قال: فاذكر منه شيئاً؟
English: “Can you mention an example of those?” he asked.

Arabic: فقلت له: قال الله: {والمطلَّقاتُ يَتَرَبَّصْنَ بأنفسِهِنَّ ثلاثةَ قُرُوْء} [البقرة 228] فقالت عائشة: “الأقراء الأطهار”، وقال بمثل معنى قولها زيدُ بن ثابت، وابن عمر، وغيرهما.
English: So I said, God said: «Divorced women shall wait by themselves for three menstrual cycles.» ʿĀʾishah said: “‘Cycles’ are the periods of purity.” Zayd ibn Thābit, Ibn ʿUmar, and others held something like her opinion as well.

Arabic: وقال نفر من أصحاب النبي: ” الأقراء الحيض”، فلا يُحِلُّوا المطلقةَ حتى تغتسل من الحيضة الثالثة.
English: But a small group among the Prophet’s Companions held that “cycles” are the periods of menstruation, and so they did not make the marriage of divorced women lawful until they had performed the major cleansing from menstruation three times.

Arabic: قال: فإلى أي شيء ترى ذهب هؤلى وهؤلى؟
English: “How did the two groups arrive at their respective conclusions?” he asked.

Arabic: قلت: تجُمع الأقراء أنها أوقات، والأوقاتُ في هذا علامات تمرُّ على المطلقات، تحُبس بها عن النكاح حتى تستكملها.
English: What “cycles” have in common, I replied, is that they refer to times, and the times in this case are signs that accompany a divorced woman and that prevent her from marrying until she completes them.

Arabic: وذهب من قال” الأقراء الحيض” – فيما نُرى والله أعلم – إلى أن قال: إن المواقيت أقلُّ الأسماء، لأنها أوقات، والأوقات أقل مما بينها، كما حُدُوُد الشيء أقلُّ مما بينها،
English: So those who said that “cycles” are the periods of menstruation, as far as we can tell, though God knows best, adopted the position that times are the terms with the narrowest meaning, because the “cycles” are points in time, and points in time are shorter than the interval between those times, just as the edges of an object cover a smaller area than what lies between them.

Arabic: والحيضُ أقل من الطُّهر،
English: Periods of menstruation are shorter than periods of purity.

Arabic: فهو في اللغة أَولى للعِدَّة أن يكون وقتاً، كما يكونُ الهلال وقتاً فاصلاً بين الشهرين.
English: So linguistically, it is more appropriate that the waiting period be relative to a point in time, just as the crescent moon is a point in time that provides a division between two months.

Arabic: ولعله ذهب إلى أن النبي أمر في سَبيْ أوطاسٍ أن يُسْتَبْرَينَ قبل أن يُوطَينَ بحيضة،
English: Perhaps they adopted the view of the Prophet when he commanded that the female prisoners taken at Awṭās be absolved of suspicion of pregnancy by completing a menstrual period before being made available for sexual intercourse.

Arabic: فذهب إلى أن العِدة استبراء، وأن الاستبراء حيضٌ،
English: They would thus have taken the view that the relevant waiting period was such absolution and that such absolution should be measured as one menstrual period.

Arabic: وأنه فرَقَ بين استبراء الأمة والحرة،
English: Furthermore, they would have differentiated between such absolution for female slaves and for free women.

Arabic: وأن الحرة تُستبرأ بثلاث حِيَض كواملَ، تخرج منها إلى الطُّهر كما تُستبرأ الأمة بحيضة كاملة، تخرج منها إلى الطُّهر.
English: Free women would be absolved after three complete menstrual periods, from which they would emerge into a state of ritual purity, just as the female slaves would do after one complete menstrual period.

Arabic: فقال: هذا مذهب، فكيف اخترتَ غيره، والآية محتملة للمعنيين عندك؟
English: “That is one approach,” he said, “but how did you select a different approach, since the verse could, in your view, be interpreted to have either meaning?”

Arabic: قال: فقلت له: إن الوقت برؤية الأهِلَّة إنما هو علامة جعلها الله للشهور، والهلالُ غير الليل والنهار،
English: The time when the new crescent moon is seen, I replied, is a sign that God has appointed for the months, and the crescent moon is other than night and day.

Arabic: وإنما هو جِماع لثلاثين، وتسعٍ وعشرين، كما يكون الهلال الثلاثون والعشرون جماعاً يُستأنف بعده العدد،
English: Rather it is a round sum of thirty or twenty-nine days and nights, just as the crescent moon, thirty, and ten plus twenty all equate to round sums after which the sequence of numbers resumes.

Arabic: وليس له معنى هنا،
English: It has no meaning other than this.

Arabic: وأن القُرْء وإن كان وقتاً فهو من عدد الليل والنهار، والحيضُ والطهر في الليل والنهار من العدة،
English: So the “cycle,” although it is a point in time, is also made up of a number of days and nights, and menstruation and the state of purity are measured according to the days and nights of the waiting period.

Arabic: وكذلك شُبِّه الوقت بالحدود، وقد تكون داخلة فيما حُدَّت به، وخارجةً منه غيرَ بائن منها، فهو وقت معنى.
English: The time in question was likened to the endpoints of that period of time, and those endpoints could possibly be both included within what bounds it and stand outside of it, but would not be separate from it, and would remain conceptually a point in time.

Arabic: قال: وما المعنى؟
English: “What does that mean?” he asked.

Arabic: قلت: الحيض هو أن يُرخِيَ الرَّحمُ الدمَ حتى يظهر، والطُّهر أن يَقْري الرَّحِمُ الدمَ فلا يظهرُ،
English: Menstruation, I replied, is the womb’s release of blood such that it comes out, and ritual purity is the womb’s retention of blood such that it does not come out.

Arabic: ويكون الطهر والقَرْي الحبس لا الإرسال،
English: Purity and retention are thus the prevention of something, not its release.

Arabic: فالطهر – إذ كان يكون وقتاً – أولى في اللسان بمعنى القُرء، لأنه حبْس الدم.
English: So if purity is a measure of time, it is linguistically more appropriate as the meaning of “cycle,” because it is the retention of blood.

Arabic: وأمر رسول الله عمرَ حين طلَّق عبدُ الله بن عمر امرأته حائضاً أن يأمره برَجعتها وحَبسِها حتى تطهر، ثم يطلِّقُها طاهراً من غير جماع،
English: God’s Emissary commanded ʿUmar to order his son ʿAbdallāh ibn ʿUmar, who had divorced his wife while she was menstruating, to take her back and to sequester her until she achieved a state of purity, and then to divorce her while in a state of purity, without having had sexual intercourse with her.

Arabic: وقال رسول الله: ” فتلك العِدَّةُ التي أمر الله أن يُطلَّق لها النساءُ” . يعني قول الله – والله أعلم – إذا طلَّقتُمُ النساءَ فطلِّقوهنَّ لِعِدَِّتهِنَّ} [الطلاق 1] ، فأخبر رسول الله أن العدةَ الطهرُ دون الحيض.
English: God’s Emissary said: “That is the waiting period according to which God commanded that one divorce women.” This referred, though God knows best, to His word «When you divorce women, divorce them at the end of their waiting period.» So God’s Emissary reported that the waiting period consisted of states of purity, not menstruation.

Arabic: وقال الله: {ثلاثة قروء} وكان على المُطَلَّقة أن تأتي بثلاثة قروء،
English: God also said: «three menstrual cycles,» it being incumbent on a divorced woman to complete three menstrual cycles.

Arabic: فكان الثالثُ لو أبطأ عن وقته زماناً لم َتحِلَّ حتى يكون، أو تُويَسَ من المحيض، أو ُيخافَ ذلك عليها،
English: If the third cycle is later than its usual time, she is not lawful until it comes or she reaches menopause, or one suspects that to be the case.

Arabic: فتَعْتَدَّ بالشهور، لم يكن للغُسل معنى، لأن الغسل رابعٌ غيرُ ثلاثة،
English: In the latter case, she must wait for a period consisting of months, and there is no point to the requirement of major cleansing, because such a cleansing would mark a fourth time period, apart from the preceding three.

Arabic: ويلزم مَن قال: ” الغسل عليها ” أن يقول: لو أقامت سنةً وأكثر لا تغتسل لم تحِلَّ!!
English: Whoever holds that such a cleansing is incumbent on her is compelled to say that if she remains a year or more without having undertaken such a cleansing, she is not lawful to marry.

Arabic: فكان قول من قال” الأقراء الأطهار ” أشبهَ بمعنى كتاب الله، واللسانُ واضح على هذه المعاني، والله أعلم.
English: Thus, the opinion of those who say that “cycles” are states of purity more closely accords with the meaning of God’s Book. The Arabic language, too, is clearly in accord with those meanings, though God knows best.

Arabic: فأما أمر النبي أن يُستبرأ السَّبْي بحيضة فبالظاهر،
English: The Prophet’s command that female slaves be absolved of suspicion of pregnancy by waiting one menstrual period should be interpreted according to its apparent meaning.

Arabic: لأن الطهر إذا كان متقدِّماً للحيضة ثم حاضت الأمة حيضة كاملة صحيحة بَرِئَت من الحَبَلِ في الطهر،
English: This is because if a state of purity precedes menstruation and then the female slave has a complete and valid menstrual period, she is absolved of the possibility of pregnancy during the ensuing period of purity.

Arabic: وقد ترى الدمَ فلا يكون صحيحاً، إنما يصح حيضةً بأن تُكمل الحيضة
English: She might see some blood but that would not count as menstrual blood since menstruation is only legally relevant if it comprises a complete menstrual period.

Arabic: فبأي شيء من الطهر كان قبل حيضة كاملة فهو براءة من الحَبَل في الظاهر.
English: So no matter whether the state of purity was before the complete and valid menstrual period, she is prima facie absolved from any suspicion of pregnancy.

Arabic: والمعتدة تَعْتدُّ بمعنيين: استبراءٌٍ، ومعنى غيرُِ استبراءٍ مع استبراء،
English: Thus, the woman who is subject to the waiting period waits in two senses: for absolution from suspicion of pregnancy and for another reason besides that concurrently.

Arabic: فقد جاءت بحيضتين وطُهرين وطهرٍ ثالث،
English: She has two menstrual periods, two periods of purity, and then a third period of purity.

Arabic: فلو أريد بها الاستبراء كانت قد جاءت بالاستبراء مرتين، ولكنه أريد بها مع الاستبراء التَعَبُّد.
English: If the point had only been for her to be absolved of suspicion of pregnancy, then she would have been so absolved twice, but such absolution was required of her in addition to the obligation to wait for the sake of fulfilling a religious obligation.

Arabic: قال: أفتوجدوني في غير هذا ما اختلفوا فيه مثل هذا؟
English: “Can you give me another example of a case,” he asked, “about which they similarly disagreed?”

Arabic: قلت: نعم، وربما وجدناه أوضحَ،
English: Yes, I replied, and maybe even something that we find to be clearer.

Arabic: وقد بيَّنا بعض هذا فيما اختلفت الرواية فيه من السنة، وفيه دلالة لك على ما سألتَ عنه، وما كان في معناه إن شاء الله.
English: We have already discussed an instance involving an inconsistent narration of Prophetic Practice, and it provides an indication of what you have asked about and is within its scope, God willing.

Arabic: وقال الله: {والمطلقاتُ يَتَرَبَّصْن بأنفسهن ثلاثةَ قروء} [البقرة 288] وقال: {واللائي يَئِسْن من المحيض من نسائكم إن ارتَبتُم، فعِدَّتهُنَّ ثلاثةُ أشهرٍ، واللائي لم يحِضْنَ، وأولاتُ الأحمالِ أجلُهُنَّ أن يضعْنَ حملَهن} [الطلاق 4] وقال: {والذين يُتَوَفَّون منكم، ويَذَرون أزواجاً يَتَرَبَّصن بأنفسهن أربعةَ أشهر وعَشراً} [البقرة 234] فقال بعض أصحاب رسول الله: ذكر الله المطلقاتِ أن عدة الحوامل أن يضعْن حملَهن، وذكر في المتوفَّى عنها أربعةَ أشهر وعشراً،
English: God said: «Divorced women shall wait by themselves for three menstrual cycles.» He also said: «With those of your women who have reached menopause, if you have doubts, their waiting period is three months; likewise the barren. For pregnant women, the period shall be until they give birth» and «Those of you who are taken in death and leave wives, the wives shall wait by themselves for four months and ten days.» One of the Companions of God’s Emissary held as follows: For pregnant divorced women, God mentioned that their waiting period should last until they give birth, and for widows, that it should be four months and ten days.

Arabic: فعلى الحامل المتوفى عنها أن تعتدَّ أربعة أشهر وعشراً، وأن تضع حمْلَها، حتى تأتي بالعدتين معاً إذا لم يكن وضعُ الحمل انقضاءَ العدة نصاً إلا في الطلاق.
English: Thus, the pregnant widow must wait four months and ten days, and she must also give birth in order to satisfy the two waiting periods together, since giving birth does not, according to an explicit revealed text, signal the end of the waiting period except in regard to divorce.

Arabic: كأنه يذهب إلى أن وضع الحمل براءةٌ، وأن الأربعة الأشهر وعشراً تَعَبُّدٌ،
English: It is as though he took the position that giving birth releases her from one obligation, but that the four months and ten days remains a religious obligation to which she is subject for its own sake.

Arabic: وأن المتوفى عنها تكون غيرَ مدخول بها، فتأتي بأربعة أشهر،
English: No marriage may be consummated with the widow; she must complete the four months’ waiting period.

Arabic: وأنه وجب عليها شيءٌ من وجهين، فلا تسقط أحدهما،
English: She thus has two different obligations, one of which does not lapse.

Arabic: كما لو وجبَ عليها حقَّان لرجلين لم يُسقط أحدُهما حقَّ الآخر،
English: It is as though she were liable to two different men for two different things, and satisfying the one liability does not cause the other one to lapse.

Arabic: وكما إذا نَكَحَت في عدتها، وأُصيبت اعتدَّت من الأول، واعتدَّت من الآخِرِ.
English: Or it is as if she married during her waiting period and had sexual intercourse: she would still be subject to the waiting period in regard to the first man and to another waiting period for the second.

Arabic: قال: وقال غيره من أصحاب رسول الله: إذا وضعَتْ ذا بطنِها، فقد حَلَّت، ولو كان زوجها على السرير.
English: Another of the Companions of God’s Emissary held: If she gives birth to the child she is carrying, she becomes lawful to marry, even if her husband is still on the funeral bier.

Arabic: قال “الشافعي”: فكانت الآية محتملةَ المعنيين معاً،
English: Al-Shāfiʿī said: The verse could have these two different meanings simultaneously.

Arabic: وكان أشبهَهَما بالمعقول الظاهرِ أن يكون الحملُ انقضاءَ العدة.
English: The meaning that seems to accord best with reason is that the pregnancy’s term constitutes the expiration of the waiting period.

Arabic: قال: فدلت سنة رسول الله على أن وضعَ الحمل آخرُ العدة في الموت، مِثلُ معناه الطلاق. ُ
English: The Practice of God’s Emissary indicates that giving birth ends the waiting period in cases of the husband’s death, just as it constitutes the rationale in the case of divorce.

Arabic: أخبرنا سفيان عن الزهري عن عبيد الله بن عبد الله عن أبيه “أن سُبَيْعَةَ الأسلَمِية وضعت بعد وفاة زوجها بليالٍ، فمَرَّ بها أبو السَّنابل بن بَعْكَكٍ، فقال: قد تَصَنَّعتِ للأزواج! إنها أربعةَ أشهر وعشراً، فذكرت ذلك سُبَيعة لرسول الله، فقال: كذب أبو السنابل، أَو ليس كما قال أبو السنابل، قد حَلَلتِ فتزوجي”.
English: Sufyān reported to us from al-Zuhrī, from ʿUbaydallāh ibn ʿAbdallāh, from his father: Subayʿah of the Aslam tribe gave birth a few nights after her husband’s death. Abū l-Sanābil ibn Baʿkak passed by her and said, “You have adorned yourself for marriage too soon; you must wait four months and ten days.” Subayʿah mentioned this to God’s Emissary, and he said: “Abū l-Sanābil lied,” or “It is not as Abū l-Sanābil said. You are lawful, so marry!”

Arabic: فقال: أما ما دلت عليه السنة فلا حجة في أحد خالف قولُه السنةَ، ولكن اذكُرْ من خلافهم ما ليس فيه نصُّ سنة مما دل عليه القُرَآن نصاً واستنباطاً، أو دلَّ عليه القياس؟
English: “Those who disagree with this Prophetic practice,” he said, “can adduce no contrary authority at all. But mention a disagreement of theirs in which there is no textually explicit account of a Prophetic practice, but for which the Qurʾan provides the indication, whether through an explicit text or one adduced through inference, or where analogical reasoning does so.”

Arabic: فقلت له: قال الله: {للذين يُؤْلون من نسائهم تَرَبُّصُ أربعة أشهر، فإن فاؤوا، فإن الله غفور رحيم، وإن عَزَمُوا الطلاقَ، فإن الله سميع عليم} [البقرة 226، 227] فقال الأكثر ممن رُوي عنه من أصحاب النبي عندنا: إذا مضت أربعة أشهر وُقف المُولي، فإما أن يفيء، وإما أن يُطَلِّق.
English: I said to him: God said: «For those who forswear their women there is a wait of four months; if they return, God is Forgiving and Merciful. If they decide on divorce—God is Hearing and Knowing.» The majority of the Prophet’s Companions whose views are narrated hold, in our view, that if the four months pass, then the person who forswears has two options: he may either return to his wife or divorce her.

Arabic: وروي عن غيرهم من أصحاب النبي: عزيمةُ الطلاق انقضاءُ أربعة أشهر.
English: It is narrated from other of the Prophet’s Companions, however, that the decision to divorce is compelled by the lapsing of the four months.

Arabic: ولم ُيحفظ عن رسول الله في هذا – بأبي هو وأمي – شيئاً .
English: Nothing at all is preserved from God’s Emissary (may my father and mother be his ransom) about this.

Arabic: قال: فأي القولين ذهبتَ؟
English: “So,” he inquired, “which of the two opinions did you adopt?”

Arabic: قلت: ذهبت إلى أن المُولي لا يلزمه طلاقٌ، وأن امرأته إذا طلبت حقها منه لم أَعرِض له حتى تمضي أربعة أشهر،
English: I hold, I replied, that the one who forswears is not bound to divorce and that if his wife demands her rights from him, I will not broach this with him until the four months have lapsed.

Arabic: فإذا مضت أربعة أشهر قلت له: فِئ أو طلِّقْ، والفيئةُ الجماعُ.
English: If the four months lapse, then I say to him, “Return or divorce!” and returning means having sexual intercourse.

Arabic: قال: فكيف اخترتَه على القول الذي يخالفه؟
English: “How,” he asked, “did you choose this over the competing opinion?”

Arabic: قلت: رأيته أشبه بمعنى كتاب الله وبالمعقول.
English: In my view, I replied, it seems more like the rationale in God’s Book, and better accords with reason.

Arabic: قال: وما دل عليه من كتاب الله؟
English: “What indication of it is there in God’s Book?” he asked.

Arabic: قلت: لما قال الله: {للذين يُؤلون من نسائهم تَرَبُّصُ أربعةَ اشهر} : كان الظاهر في الآية أن من أنظَرَه الله أربعة أشهر في شيء، لم يكن له عليه سبيل حتى تمضي أربعةُ أشهر.
English: I said: When God said “For those who forswear their women there is a wait of four months,” the verse’s apparent meaning is that for whomever God granted a postponement of something for four months, the person in question cannot by any means do that thing until the four months have elapsed.

Arabic: قال: فقد يحتمل أن يكون الله عز وجل جعل له أربعة أشهر يفيءُ فيها، كما تقول: قد أجَّلتك في بناء هذه الدار أربعة اشهر تفرُغُ فيها منها؟
English: “But,” he said, “God (mighty and sublime) granted him four months during which he could return to her, as when you say, ‘I give you a period of four months to build this house, during which time you must finish it.’”

Arabic: قال: فقلت له: هذا لا يتوهمه مَن خوطب به حتى يُشترط في سياق الكلام،
