English: No one who is addressed by this would imagine that, I replied, unless the structure of the sentence somehow implied it.

Arabic: ولو قال قد أجلتك فيها أربعة أشهر: كان إنما أجله أربعة أشهر لا يجد عليه سبيلاً حتى تنقضي
English: If someone were to say, “I give you a period of four months’ delay for it,” he would have given him a four-month deadline but have no recourse against him until they expired.

Arabic: ولم يفرُغ منها، فلا يُنسب إليه أن لم يفرغ من الدار، وأنه أخلف في الفراغ منها ما بقي من الأربعة الأشهر شيء،
English: If the builder had not finished building it during that time, then one could not impute to him the failure to build it or that he had breached his promise to finish it, as long as the four-month period had not expired.

Arabic: فإذا لم يبقَ منها شيء لَزِمَه اسم الخُلْف،
English: If they had elapsed, then the term “breach of promise,” could be applied to him.

Arabic: وقد يكون في بناء الدار دلالةٌ على أن يقارِبَ الأربعةَ، وقد بقي منها ما يحيط العلم أنه لا يبنيه فيما بقي من الأربعة.
English: It might be true that the progress of construction would indicate that, as the end of the four months approached, he would certainly not finish it in the remaining time.

Arabic: وليس في الفيئة دلالةٌ على أن لا يفيء الأربعة إلا مُضِيُّها لأن الجماع يكون في طَرفة عين،
English: In the case of returning to his wife, however, there is no indication that he might not return before the four months have expired, since sexual intercourse can occur in the blink of an eye.

Arabic: فلو كان على ما وصفتَ تَزَايَلَ حاله حتى تمضي أربعة أشهر، ثم تَزَايل حاله الأولى،
English: If things were to happen as you have stated, his situation changes until the four months elapse, and then that situation changes.

Arabic: فإذا زايلها صار إلى أن الله عليه حقاً، فإما أن يفيء وإما أن يطلِّق.
English: Once he exits from that situation, he becomes subject to God’s claim and then must either return to her or divorce her.

Arabic: فلو لم يكن في آخر الآية ما يدل على معناها غيرُ ما ذهبتَ إليه، كان قوله أَولاهما بها، لما وصفنا، لأنه ظاهرها.
English: If there were not something at the end of the verse that indicates that its meaning is other than what you concluded, then that opinion would be the better of the two in regard to it, because of what I have explained, to wit, that it is the most apparent meaning.

Arabic: والقُرَآن على ظاهره، حتى تأتي دلالة منه أو سنة أو إجماع بأنه على باطن دون ظاهر.
English: The Qurʾan is interpreted according to its apparent meaning unless there is some other indication from it itself, or a Prophetic practice, or consensus, that its true meaning is other than its apparent meaning.

Arabic: قال: فما في سياق الآية ما يدل على ما وصفتَ؟
English: “What in the verse’s sentence structure,” he asked, “indicates what you have just described?”

Arabic: قلت: لما ذكر الله عز وجل أن للمُولي أربعةَ أشهر، ثم قال: {فإن فاؤوا فإن الله غفور رحيم، وإن عزموا الطلاق فإن الله سميع عليم} ، فذكر الحُكمين معاً بلا فصل بينهما: أنهما إنما يقعان بعد الأربعة الأشهر،
English: I said: When God (mighty and sublime) stated that the one who forswears has four months and then said, “If they return, God is Forgiving and Merciful. If they decide on divorce—God is Hearing and Knowing,” He mentioned the two rules together, without separating them, stating that they come into force only after the four months.

Arabic: لأنه إنما جَعَل عليه الفيئة أو الطلاق، وجعل له الخيار فيهما في وقت واحد، فلا يتقدم واحد منهما صاحبه،
English: This is because He let him only either return or divorce, thus giving him the choice between the two, at one time; so neither option may precede its counterpart.

Arabic: وقد ذُكرا في وقت واحد، كما يقال له في الرهن افْدِهِ أو نبيعَه عليك بلا فصل،
English: They were both mentioned as occurring during one and the same period of time, just as one says in regard to something pledged, “Redeem it or we will sell it against your will,” without separating the two.

Arabic: وفي كل ما خُيرِّ فيه: افعل كذا أو كذا، بلا فصل.
English: So, too, for anything in which one is given two options: “Do the one or the other,” without separating the two.

Arabic: ولا يجوز أن يكونا ذُكرا بلا فصل، فيقالَ: الفيئة فيما بين أن يُولي أربعة أشهر وعزيمةُ الطلاق انقضاءُ الأربعة الأشهر، فيكونان حكمين ذكرا معاً، يُفسخ في أحدهما، ويُضيَّق في الآخر.
English: It is not permissible for them to be mentioned together, without being separated, as if one said: “Returning can occur during the four months that one forswears, but the decision to divorce may occur only at the expiration of the four months.” In that case, the two rules would have been mentioned together but one of the two rules would allow wide scope for action, and the other would allow little or no scope.

Arabic: قال: فأنت تقول: إن فاءَ قبل الأربعة الأشهر فهي فيئة؟
English: “So what you are saying,” he pressed, “is that if he returns before the four months are up, that constitutes ‘returning’ for these purposes?”

Arabic: قلت: نعم، كما أقول: إن قضيتَ حقاً عليك إلى أجل قبل محله، فقد برئتَ منه، وأنت محسن متسرِّع بتقديمه قبل يحلَُّ عليك.
English: Yes, I replied, just as I would hold that if you agreed to satisfy a liability that was due after a certain period of time before the expiry of that period, and you in fact paid it off early, you would have done the right thing by hurrying to pay it off early, before it became due by reason of the expiry of the period of time.

Arabic: فقلت له: أرأيت من الإثم كان مُزمَعَاً على الفيئة في كل يوم إلا أنه لم يجامع حتى تنقضي أربعة أشهر؟
English: Do you think it is a sin, I asked him, if he resolves to return every day but nevertheless does not have sexual intercourse until the four months have elapsed?

Arabic: قال: فلا يكون الإزماع على الفيئة شيءً حتى يفيء، والفيئة الجماعُ إذا كان قادراً عليه.
English: “His resolve to return means nothing,” he responded, “until he actually returns, and ‘returning’ is sexual intercourse, if he is physically capable of it.”

Arabic: قلت: ولو جامع لا ينوي فيئة خرج من طلاق الإيلَى، لأن المعنى في الجماع؟
English: If he were to have sexual intercourse, I said, but without intending to return, then he would no longer be subject to the divorce otherwise required by his forswearing, since the occurrence of sexual intercourse resolves the whole matter.

Arabic: قال: نعم.
English: “Yes.”

Arabic: قلت: وكذلك لو كان عازماً على ان لا يفيء، يحلفُ في كل يوم ألا يفيء، ثم جامع قبل مُضِي الأربعة الأشهر بطرْفة عين: خرج من طلاق الإيلَى؟ وإن كان جماعه لغير الفيئة خرج به من طلاق الإيلى؟
English: If, I continued, he were resolved not to return, swearing every day not to return, and then had sexual intercourse just before the lapse of the four months by the blink of an eye, he would no longer be subject to the divorce otherwise required by his forswearing—even if the sexual intercourse occurred for some purpose other than his returning to her, he would no longer be subject to such a divorce?

Arabic: قال: نعم.
English: “Yes.”

Arabic: قلت: ولا يصنعُ عزمُهُ على ألا يفيء؟ ولا يمنعه جماعه بلذَّة لغير الفيئة، إذا جاء بالجماع: مِن أن يخرج به من طلاق الإيلى عندنا وعندك؟
English: So, I continued, his resolve not to return has no effect, and his having sexual intercourse—for pleasure, not for the purpose of returning—if he does have sexual intercourse, does not, in our view or in yours, prevent him from ceasing to be subject to such a divorce based on forswearing?

Arabic: قال: هذا كما قلتَ، وخروجُهُ بالجماع على أي معنى كان الجماع.
English: “That is as you say,” he replied. “He ceases to be subject to divorce by reason of sexual intercourse, for whatever reason it occurred.”

Arabic: قلت: فكيف يكون عازماً على أن لا يفيء في كل يوم، فإذا مضت أربعة أشهر لزمه الطلاق، وهو لم يعزم عليه، ولم يتكلم به؟ أترى هذا قولاً يصح في العقول لأحد؟!
English: So how, I asked, could he be resolved on returning every single day and then, once the four months have passed, the divorce becomes binding on him, when he did not intend to divorce and did not even speak about it? Can anyone hold that such an opinion validly accords with reason?

Arabic: قال: فما يُفسده من قبل العقول؟
English: “What,” he asked, “invalidates it from the point of view of reason?”

Arabic: قلت: أرأيت إذا قال الرجل لامرأته: والله لا أقربُك أبداً: أهو كقوله: أنت طالق إلى أربعة أشهر؟
English: What do you think, I inquired, of the situation when a man says to his wife, “By God, I will not come near you, ever”? Is that like when he says, “You are divorced after four months”?

Arabic: قال: إن قلتُ نعم؟
English: “What if I say ‘yes’?” he asked.

Arabic: قلتُ: فإن جامع قبل الأربعة؟
English: And if he has sexual intercourse with her, I continued, before the four months are up?

Arabic: قال: فلا، ليس مثلَ قوله: أنتِ طالق إلى أربعة أشهر.
English: “Then, no,” he replied, “it is not like his saying ‘You are divorced after four months.’”

Arabic: قال: فتكلُّمُ المُولي بالإيلى ليس هو طلاقً،
English: When the person who forswears utters a vow to that effect, doing so does not constitute a divorce.

Arabic: إنما هي يمين،
English: Rather, it is merely an oath.

Arabic: ثم جاءت عليها مُدة جعلتها طلاقاً، أيجوز لأحد يعقل من حيث يقولُ أن يقول مثل هذا إلا بخبر لازم؟! قال: فهو يدخل عليك مثلُ هذا.
English: So can a period of time supervene and make it into a divorce? Is it permissible for anyone who has any rational understanding at all of the source of their legal opinions to hold such a view—unless it is based on a binding report? “A similar point,” he said, “could be raised against you as an objection.”

Arabic: قلت: وأين؟
English: How so?

Arabic: قال: أنت تقول إذا مضت أربعة أشهر وُقف، فإن فاء وإلا جُبر على أن يُطلِّق.
English: “You say,” he went on, “that if four months elapse, he is then confronted with two alternatives: he may return, but otherwise he is compelled to divorce her.”

Arabic: قلت: ليس من قِبَل أن الإيلى طلاق، ولكنها يمين جعل الله لها وقتاً مَنَعَ بها الزوجَ من الضِّرار،
English: Not, I said, because the vow to forswear is tantamount to a divorce, but rather because it is an oath for which God has appointed a fixed time in order to spare the spouse harm.

Arabic: وحكم عليه إذا كانت أن جَعَل عليه إما أن يفيء، وإما أن يُطَلق،
English: The ruling is made according to the oath, since he must either return to her or divorce her.

Arabic: وهذا حكم حادث بمُضِي أربعة الأشهر، غيرُ الإيلى، ولكنه مؤتَنَف ُيجبر صاحبه على أن يأتي بأيهما شاء: فيئةٌٍ أو طلاقٌٍ،
English: The rule comes into force with the lapse of the four months, distinct from the vow to forswear, but it creates a new situation: the person who made the vow is compelled to do whichever of the two he wishes, return or divorce.

Arabic: فإن امتنع منهما أُخذ منه الذي يُقدر على أخذه منه، وذلك أن يُطلَّق عليه، لأنه لا يحل أن ُيجامَعَ عنه.
English: If he refuses to do either, one finds against him based on what one is capable of compelling him to do, that is, he is forcibly divorced, since one cannot have sexual intercourse on his behalf.

Arabic: واختلفوا في المواريث،
English: They also disagreed concerning inheritance shares.

Arabic: فقال زيد بن ثابت ومن ذهب مذهبه: يعطى كل وارث ما ُسمِّي له، فإن فَضَل فضل ولا عَصَبَة للميت ولا ولاءَ: كان ما بقي لجماعة المسلمين.
English: Zayd ibn Thābit and those who followed his view held that every Qurʾanic heir is awarded his or her specified share, and if something is left over and the deceased has no male agnates and no contractual heirs, then whatever is left over reverts to the Muslim community.

Arabic: وعن غيره منهم: أنه كان يردُّ فضل المواريث على ذوي الأرحام،
English: It is narrated by others that any residual amount reverts to cognates and non-Qurʾanic female agnates.

Arabic: فلو أن رجلاً ترك أخته، ورثَتْه النصفَ ورُدَّ عليها النصفُ.
English: Thus, if a man were survived by a sister only, she would inherit half the estate from him as a Qurʾanic heir, and the residual amount would revert to her as a non-Qurʾanic female agnate.

Arabic: فقال بعض الناس: لمَ لم تردَّ فضل المواريث؟
English: Someone asked me, “Why don’t you let the excess amount revert to the sister?”

Arabic: قلت: استدلالاً بكتاب الله.
English: By reason, I replied, of an inference based on the Book of God.

Arabic: قال: وأين يدل كتاب الله على ما قلت؟
English: “But where,” he asked, “does God’s Book indicate what you hold?”

Arabic: قلت: قال الله: {إنِ امرؤٌ هلك ليس له ولدٌ وله أختٌ فلها نصفُ ما ترك، وهو يرِثها إن لم يكن لها ولدٌ} [النساء 176] وقال: {وإن كانوا أخوةً رجالاً ونساءً، فللذَّكر مثلُ حظِّ الأنثيين} [النساء 176] فذكر الأخت منفردةً، فانتهى بها جل ثناؤه إلى النصف، والأخَ منفرداً، فانتهى به إلى الكلِّ
English: God said: «If a man perishes and has no children, but he has a sister, she receives half of what he leaves. He inherits from her if she has no children» and He said «If there are both brothers and sisters, the male gets a share equivalent to the share of two sisters.» God mentioned the sister by herself and (sublime His praise) allotted one-half to her, and He mentioned the brother by himself and allotted the entirety to him.

Arabic: وذكر الأخوة والأخوات، فجعل للأخت نصفَ ما للأخ.
English: He also mentioned brothers and sisters and assigned to the sister one-half of what is awarded to the brother.

Arabic: وكان حكمه – جل ثناؤه – في الأخت منفردةً ومع الأخ سواءً، بأنها لا تساوي الأخَ، وأنها تأخذ النصف مما يكون له من الميراث.
English: His ruling concerning the sister (sublime His praise), whether by herself or together with the brother, is the same, in the sense that she is not equal to the brother, and takes half of that amount of the estate that is due to him.

Arabic: فلو قلتَ في رجل مات، وترك أخته: لها النصفُ بالميراث وأردُدُ عليها النصف: كنتَ قد أعطيتها الكل منفردة،
English: If you were to say, in regard to a man who died and left a sister, that she gets half the estate, and I let the other half revert to her, then you would be giving her the entirety by herself.

Arabic: وإنما جعل الله لها النصف في الانفراد والاجتماع.
English: But God only assigned to her onehalf, whether by herself or together with another heir.

Arabic: فقال: فإني لست أعطيها النصف الباقي ميراثاً، إنما أعطيها إياه رداً.
English: “I do not award her the remaining one-half as an inheritance share,” he said, “but rather, I award it to her as a residual amount.”

Arabic: قلت: وما معنى “رداً” أشيء استحسنته، وكان إليك أن تضعه حيث شئتَ؟ فإن شئتَ أن تعطيه جيرانه أو بعيدَ النسب منه، أيكون ذلك لك؟!
English: So I said: What do you mean by “residual”? Is it something arrived at on the basis of subjective reasoning, such that you can assign it wherever you wish? So if you wished to give it to his neighbors, or to an extremely distant relative of the deceased, is that something you would be allowed to do?

Arabic: قال: ليس ذلك للحاكم، ولكن جعلتُهُ رداً عليها بالرَّحِم.
English: “That,” he replied, “is not allowed for any judge to do. Rather, I assigned it to her as a residual amount, but on the basis of her uterine relationship to the deceased.”

Arabic: ميراثاً؟
English: So: as an inheritance share?

Arabic: قال: فإن قلتُه؟
English: “What if I say that?”

Arabic: قلت: إذن تكون ورَّثتها غيرَ ما ورَّثها الله.
English: In that case, I said, you will have made her inherit in a way other than the way God made her inherit.

Arabic: قال: فأقول: لك ذلك، لقول الله: {وأُولوا الأرحام بعضُهم أولى ببعض في كتاب الله} [الأنفال 75]
English: “My opinion is that you can do that because God says «Some blood relations are nearer than others in God’s decree.»”

Arabic: فقلت له: {وأولوا الأرحام بعضهم أولى ببعض} نزلت بأن الناس توارثوا بالحِلف،
English: I replied, The verse “Some blood relations are nearer than others” was revealed because people used to inherit from one another based on affiliation.

Arabic: ثم توارثوا بالإسلام والهجرة، فكان المهاجر يرث المهاجر، ولا يرثه من ورثته مَن لم يكن مهاجراً، وهو أقرب إليه ممن وَرِثه،
English: Then their relationships as heirs came to be based on Islam and the emigration from Mecca to Medina, so that the Emigrants would inherit from each other, and any of their heirs who had not emigrated would not inherit, even though they were more closely related to the deceased than those who did inherit.

Arabic: فنزلت {وأولوا الأرحام} الآية على ما فُرِضَ لهم.
English: The verse “Some blood relations are nearer than others” refers to the shares that He apportioned to them at that time.

Arabic: قال: فاذكر الدليل على ذلك؟
English: “Can you mention what it is that indicates that?” he asked.

Arabic: قلت: {وأولوا الأرحام بعضهم أولى ببعض في كتاب الله} : على ما فُرِضَ لهم،
English: The verse “Some blood relations are nearer than others in God’s decree” concerns what He apportioned to them.

Arabic: ألا ترى أن من ذوي الأرحام من يرث، ومنهم من لا يرث، وأن الزوج يكون أكثرَ ميراثا من أكثر ذوي الأرحام ميراثاً؟ وأنك لو كنت إنما تُوَرِّث بالرحم كانت رحم البنت من الأب كرحم الابن؟ وكان ذوو الأرحام يرثون معاً، ويكونون أحقَّ من الزوج الذي لا رحم له؟!
English: Is it not the case that there are, among the cognates and non-Qurʾanic female agnates, some who inherit and some who do not, and that the spouse is awarded a larger share than most of the cognates and non-Qurʾanic female agnates? If you award shares according to uterine relationships, then the daughter’s relationship will be the same as the son’s, and the cognates and non-Qurʾanic female agnates will inherit together and be more entitled than the spouse, who has no uterine tie to the deceased at all.

Arabic: ولو كانت الآية كما وصفتَ كنتَ قد خالفتها فيما ذكرنا، في أن يترك أخته ومَوَاليَه
English: Indeed, if the verse is as you characterize it, then you have contradicted it in the case we mentioned, in which the deceased is survived by his sister and contractual heirs, and she is more closely related to him.

Arabic: فتُعطيَ أخته النصف، ومواليه النصف، وليسوا بذَوِي أرحام، ولا مفروضًٍ لهم في كتاب الله فرضٌ منصوص.
English: You would give the sister half and the contractual heirs half, even though they are not cognates or nonQurʾanic female agnates and receive no Qurʾanic share mentioned in an explicit text from God’s Book.

Arabic: واختلفوا في الجد،
English: They disagreed over the inheritance share of the grandfather.

Arabic: فقال زيد بن ثابت، وروي عن عمر وعثمان وعلي وابن مسعود: يُوَرَّث معه الأخوة.
English: Zayd ibn Thābit held—and this has been narrated from ʿUmar, ʿUthmān, ʿAlī, and Ibn Masʿūd—that brothers of the deceased should inherit along with him.

Arabic: وقال أبو بكر الصديق وابن عباس، وروي عن عائشة وابن الزبير وعبد الله بن عُتبة: أنهم جعلوه أباً، وأسقطوا الإخوة معه.
English: Abū Bakr al-Ṣiddīq and Ibn ʿAbbās held—and this has also been narrated from ʿĀʾishah, Ibn al-Zubayr, and ʿAbdallāh ibn ʿUtbah—that they put the grandfather in the position of the father and excluded the brothers if the grandfather survived the deceased.

Arabic: فقال: فكيف صرتم إلى أن ثبَّتم ميراث الإخوة مع الجد؟ أَبِدِلالةٍ من كتاب الله أو سنةٍ؟
English: “How,” he asked, “did you come to confirm that both the brothers and the grandfather should inherit if they survive the deceased? Is this based on an indication from God’s Book or a Prophetic practice?”

Arabic: قلت: أما شيء مبيَّنٌ في كتاب الله أو سنةٍ فلا أعلمه.
English: As for something clearly stated in God’s Book or an account of Prophetic practice, I know of none.

Arabic: قال: فالأخبارُ متكافئة، والدلائلُ بالقياس مع من جعله أباً وحَجَبَ به الأخوةَ.
English: “But,” he said, “the reports are equivocal in regard to this, and the indications arrived at by means of analogy support the view of those who put the grandfather in the position of a father and have him exclude the brothers.”

Arabic: قلت: وأين الدلائل؟
English: Where are these indications? I inquired.

Arabic: قال: وجدت اسم الأُبُوَّة تلزمه، ووجدتكم مجتمعين على أن تحجُبُوا به بني الأم، ووجدتكم لا تنقُصونه من السدس، وذلك كله حكمُ الأب.
English: “I think,” he replied, “that the concept ‘fatherhood’ applies to him, that you agree that he excludes the mother’s sons, and that you do not reduce his share to less than one-sixth. All of that applies by rule to the father.”

Arabic: فقلت له: ليس باسم الأبوة فقط نُوَرِّثه.
English: We do not make him an heir, I explained, solely on the grounds of the concept of fatherhood.

Arabic: قال: وكيف ذلك؟
English: “How so?”

Arabic: قلت: أجد اسم الأبوة يلزمه، ولا يرث.
English: I might find that the concept of “fatherhood” applies to him in some cases when he does not inherit.

Arabic: قال: وأين؟
English: “When?”

Arabic: قلت: قد يكون دونه أبٌ، واسم الأبوة تلزمه، وتلزم آدمَ،
English: There might be another father, I said, in addition to him. The concept of fatherhood applies to him and also to Adam.

Arabic: وإذا كان دون الجد أبٌ لم يرث،
English: If there is a father in addition to the grandfather, then the grandfather does not inherit.

Arabic: ويكون مملوكاً وكافراً وقاتلاً فلا يرث،
English: Moreover, if he is a slave, a nonbeliever, or the killer of the deceased, he does not inherit.

Arabic: واسم الأبوة في هذا كله لازم له،
English: In all these cases the concept of fatherhood applies to him, too.

Arabic: فلو كان باسم الأبوة فقط يرث وَرِث في هذه الحالات.
English: So if he were to inherit solely because of the concept of fatherhood, then he would inherit in those other situations, as well.

Arabic: وأما حَجْبُنا به بني الأم، فإنما حجبنا به خبراً، لا باسم الأبوة،
English: As for our excluding the sons of the mother, we do so based on a report, not by reason of fatherhood.

Arabic: وذلك أنا نحجب بني الأم ببنت ابن ابنٍ مُتَسَفِّلةٍ.
English: That is, we exclude the mother’s sons in favor of a remote female descendant.

Arabic: وأما أنا لم نَنْقصه من السدس، فلسنا نَنقص الجدة من السدس.
English: As for the fact that we do not reduce his share to less than one-sixth, neither do we reduce the share of the grandmother below one-sixth.

Arabic: وإنما فعلنا هذا كلَّه اتباعاً، لا أن حكم الجد إذ وافق حكم الأب في معنى كان مثلَه في كلِّ معنىً،
English: We hold these positions based on fidelity to Revelation and precedent, not on the grounds that if the ruling concerning the grandfather agrees with that concerning the father in one sense, then it must do so in all cases.

Arabic: ولو كان حكم الجد إذا وافق حكم الأب في بعض المعاني كان مثلَه في كل المعاني: كانت بنتُ الابن المتَسَفِّلة موافقةً له،
English: If it were the case that the ruling concerning the grandfather agreed with that for the father—for the reason that if it is the same in some instances then it must be so in all instances—then that of the remote female descendant would agree with it.

Arabic: فإنا نحجب بها بني الأم، وحكمُ الجدة موافق له، فإنا لا ننقصها من السدس.
English: Yet we exclude the mother’s descendants because of her, and the ruling concerning the grandmother agrees with that of the grandfather—we do not reduce her share below one-sixth either.

Arabic: قال: فما حجتكم في ترك قولنا نحجُبُ بالجد الإخوة؟
English: “What authority can you cite,” he asked, “to support your rejection of our opinion that the brothers are excluded by the grandfather?”

Arabic: قلت: بُعدُ قولكم من القياس.
English: The reason, I replied, is that your opinion is far removed from analogical reasoning.

Arabic: قال: فما كنا نراه إلا بالقياس نفسه؟
English: “To us it seemed nothing but analogical reasoning itself,” he said.

Arabic: قلت: أرأيت الجدَّ والأخَ؟ أيُدلي واحد منهما بقرابة نفسه، أم بقرابة غيره؟
English: What do you think, then, about the grandfather and the brother? I asked. Does each of them establish his link to the deceased through his own relationship or by means of someone else’s relationship?

Arabic: قال: وما تعني؟
English: “What do you mean?”

Arabic: قلت: أليس إنما يقول الجد: أنا أبو أبي الميت؟! ويقول الأخ: أنا ابن أبي الميت؟!
English: Does the grandfather not say, “I am the father of the father of the deceased”? And the brother, “I am the son of the father of the deceased”?

Arabic: قال: بلى.
English: “Indeed, yes.”

Arabic: قلت: وكلاهما يُدلي بقرابة الأب بقدْر موقعه منها؟
English: So both of them establish their link through the father’s relationship to the deceased, to the extent of his position with regard to that relationship?

Arabic: قال: نعم.
English: “Yes,” he replied.

Arabic: قلت: فاجعلِ الأب الميت، وتَرَكَ ابنه وأباه، كيف ميراثهما منه؟
English: Then suppose that the father is the deceased, I said, and that he is survived by his son and his own father. How do they inherit from him?

Arabic: قال: لابنه خمسةُ أسداس، ولأبيه السدسُ
English: “His son gets five-sixths of the inheritance,” he replied, “and his father gets one-sixth.”

Arabic: قلت: فإذا كان الابن أولى بكثرة الميراث من الأب، وكان الأخُ من الأب الذي يُدلي الأخُ بقرابته، والجدُّ أبو الأب من الأب الذي يُدلي بقرابته كما وصفتَ: كيف حجبتَ الأخ بالجد؟! ولو كان أحدهما يكون محجوباً بالآخر انْبَغَى أن ُيحجب الجد بالأخ، لأنه أولاهما بكثرة ميراث الذي يُدليان معاً بقرابته، أو ُتجعلَ للأخ خمسةَ أسداس، وللجد سدسًٌ.
English: If the son is more entitled by virtue of the greater share of the inheritance from the father that is awarded to him, and the brother is descended from the father, through whom he claims a familial relation, and the grandfather is the father of the father, through whom he claims a familial relationship, as you yourself have described, then how can you exclude the grandfather? If one of them had to be excluded by the other, then the grandfather would have to be excluded by the brother, since the brother is the more worthy by virtue of the size of the inheritance shares that they receive on account of the familial relationship that each asserts. Alternatively, you could always just award the brother fivesixths and the grandfather one-sixth.

Arabic: قال: فما منعك من هذا القول؟
English: “What,” he asked, “prevents you from adopting that opinion?”

Arabic: قلت: كلُّ المختلفين مجتمعون على أن الجد مع الأخ مثلُه أو أكثر حظاً منه،
English: All those who disagree, I answered, have nevertheless reached a consensus on the view that the grandfather receives a share equal to or greater than that of the brother.

Arabic: فلم يكن لي عندي خلافُهم، ولا الذهابُ إلى القياس، والقياسُ مخرِج من جميع أقاويلهم.
English: I do not think one should contradict them or resort to analogizing when it leads to a position outside the total range of their opinions.

Arabic: وذهبتُ إلى اثبات الإخوة مع الجد، أَولى الأمرين، لما وصفتُ من الدلائل التي أوجدنيها القياسُ
English: I concluded that confirming the right of both the brothers and the grandfather to inherit together is the best of the two views on the basis of the indications that analogizing furnished me, as I have described.

Arabic: مع أن ما ذهبتُ إليه قولُ الأكثر من أهل الفقه بالبلدان قديماً وحديثاً.
English: This is especially so in conjunction with the fact that my conclusion is the opinion of most jurists in the various regions past and present.

Arabic: مع أن ميراث الإخوة ثابت في الكتاب، ولا ميراث للجد في الكتاب، وميراث الإخوة أَثبتُ في السنة من ميراث الجد.
English: In addition, the inheritance of the brothers is affirmed in the Book; the grandfather has no inheritance according to the Book; and the inheritance of the brothers is better established than that of the grandfather in Prophetic Practice.

Arabic: أقاويل الصحابة
English: Opinions of the Companions

Arabic: فقال: قد سمعت قولك في الإجماع والقياس، بعد قولك في حكم كتاب الله وسنة رسوله، أرأيت أقاويل أصحاب رسول الله إذا تفرقوا فيها؟
English: Then he said, “I have heard your opinion concerning consensus and analogizing after your opinion about rulings of the Book of God and the Practice of His Emissary. What do you think about the opinions of the Companions of God’s Emissary when they disagree with each other?”

Arabic: فقلت: نصير منها إلى ما وافق الكتاب، أو السنة، أو الإجماع، أو كان أصحَّ في القياس.
English: In that case, I said, we adopt the opinion that agrees with the Book, Prophetic Practice, consensus, or what makes for the most valid analogy.

Arabic: قال: أفرأيت إذا قال الواحد منهم القولَ لا ُيحفظ عن غيره منهم فيه له موافقةً، ولا خلافاً أتجد لك حجة باتباعه في كتاب أو سنة أو أمر أحمع الناس عليه، فيكونَ من الأسباب التي قلتَ بها خبراً؟
English: “What do you think,” he continued, “about the case in which one of them utters an opinion and no one else is remembered to have agreed or disagreed with it? Can you cite any authority for following it—whether from a scriptural passage, a Prophetic practice, or something people have agreed on—that could serve as a justification of a kind that you could adduce as a report?”

Arabic: قلت له: ما وجدنا في هذا كتاباً ولا سنةً ثابتة،
English: We have not found, I replied, any scriptural prooftext or confirmed account of a Prophetic practice pertaining to that.

Arabic: ولقد وجدنا أهل العلم يأخذون بقول واحدهم مرة، ويتركونه أخرى، ويتفرقوا في بعض ما أخذوا به منهم.
English: We have found scholars adopting the opinion of one Companion sometimes and not adopting it at other times, and also disagreeing over some of the Companions’ opinions that they do adopt.

Arabic: قال: فإلى أي شيء صرتَ من هذا؟
English: “Which of those do you do?” he asked.

Arabic: قلت: إلى اتباع قول واحد، إذا لم أجد كتاباً ولا سنة ولا إجماعاً ولا شيئاً في معناه ُيحكم له بحكمه، أو وُجد معه قياس.
English: I follow the opinion of a Companion, I said, if I cannot find a prooftext from scripture, a Prophetic practice, an instance of consensus, anything of similar import to the Companion’s opinion that would justify using his opinion as the basis for a ruling, or an illustration of how it could be used for analogical reasoning.

Arabic: وقلَّ ما يُوجَد من قول الواحد منهم، لا يخالفه غيره من هذا.
English: Only rarely does one find that the opinion of one Companion remains unopposed by another.

Arabic: [منزلة الإجماع والقياس]
English: The Status of Consensus and Analogy

Arabic: قال: فقد حكمتَ بالكتاب والسنة، فكيف حكمتَ بالإجماع، ثم حكمتَ بالقياس، فأقمتها مع كتابٍ أو سنة؟
English: “You have based rulings on the Book and Prophetic Practice,” he said. “How do you rule on the basis of consensus, and then analogies? Do you accord consensus and analogies the same status as a scriptural prooftext or a Prophetic practice?”

Arabic: فقلت: إني وإن حكمتُ بها كما احكم بالكتاب والسنة: فأصلُ ما أحكم به منها مفترقٌ.
English: Even if I do base rulings on them in the same way that I do using the Book and accounts of Prophetic Practice, I replied, the principle that underlies my rulings that I base on them differs.

Arabic: قال: أفيجوز أن تكون أصولٌ مفرَّقة الأسباب ُيحكم فيها حكماً واحداً؟
English: “Is it permissible,” he asked, “for such bases to have differing underpinnings and yet be used in issuing the same kinds of rulings?”

Arabic: قلت: نعم، ُيحكم بالكتاب والسنة المجتمع عليها، الذي لا اختلاف فيها، فنقول لهذا: حكمنا بالحق في الظاهر والباطن.
English: Yes, I answered. When one rules on the basis of the Book and widely agreed-upon instances of Prophetic Practice, concerning which there is no dispute, in such a case we say: we have ruled correctly both according to the apparent meaning and the true meaning.

Arabic: وُيحكم بالسنة قد ُرويت من طريق الانفراد، لا يجتمع الناس عليها، فنقول حكمنا بالحق في الظاهر، لأنه قد يمكن الغلط فيمن روى الحديث.
English: When one rules on the basis of an account of a Prophetic practice that has been narrated as an isolated transmission, and upon which people have not agreed, we say: we have ruled correctly, but on the basis of the apparent meaning, since it is possible for the person who related such a hadith-report to have been mistaken.

Arabic: ونحكم بالإجماع ثم القياسِ، وهو أضعف من هذا، ولكنها منزلةُ ضرورة، لأنه لا يحل القياسُ والخبرُ موجودٌ، كما يكون التيمم طهارةً في السفر عند الإعواز من الماء،
English: We rule on the basis of consensus, and then analogies, which is weaker, but they are a matter of necessity, because it is not allowed to analogize if there is an extant report, just as the performance of substitute ablutions with sand when one is traveling and lacks water allows one to achieve ritual purity.

Arabic: ولا يكون طهارةً إذا وُجد الماء، إنما يكون طهارةً في الإعواز.
English: Doing so does not allow one to achieve ritual purity if water is available, but rather it only does so if water is lacking.

Arabic: وكذلك يكون ما بعد السنة حجةً إذا أَعوَزَ من السنة.
English: So, too, what comes after Prophetic Practice can constitute authority only if an account of his Practice is lacking.

Arabic: وقد وصفتُ الحجة في القياس، وغيره قبل هذا.
English: I have discussed the authorities that support reasoning by analogy above.

Arabic: قال: أفتجد شيئا شبهه.
English: Then he said, “Can you give me an example of something that is like this?”

Arabic: قلت: نعم، أقضي على الرجل بعلمي أنَّ ما ادُّعي عليه كما ادُّعي، أو إقرارِه،
English: Yes, I said. I rule against someone on the basis of personal knowledge that what is alleged against him is as alleged, or I rule on the basis of his admission against interest.

Arabic: فإن لم أعلم ولم يُقِرَّ قضيتُ عليه بشاهدين، وقد يغلِطان ويهِمَان،
English: If I have no such knowledge, or he makes no such admission, then I would rule against him on the basis of the testimony of two witnesses, even though they might be mistaken or speculating.

Arabic: وعلمي وإقرارُه أقوى عليه من شاهدين،
English: My personal knowledge and his own admission are stronger evidence against him than the testimony of the two witnesses.

Arabic: وأقضي عليه بشاهد ويمين، وهو أضعف من شاهدين،
English: I might also rule against him on the basis of the testimony of one witness and an oath, and that is weaker than the testimony of the two witnesses.

Arabic: ثم أقضي عليه بنكوله عن اليمين ويمينِ صاحبه،
English: Then I might rule against him on the grounds of his refusal to take an oath in combination with the oath of his accuser.

Arabic: وهو أضعف من شاهد ويمين، لأنه قد ينكُل خوفَ الشهرة واستصغارَ ما يحلف عليه، ويكون الحالف لنفسه غيرَ ثقة وحريصاً فاجراً.
English: That is weaker still than the testimony of the one witness and the oath, because he might decline to take the oath out of fear of notoriety, or because he considers the matter regarding which he is asked to swear unimportant, even though the other party, who swears in his own favor, might be untrustworthy, greedy, and a sinner.

Arabic: آخر كتاب الرسالة والحمد لله وصلى الله على محمد.
English: End of the Book  The Epistle  Praise Be to God and May God Bless Muḥammad
